The Deputy Chief General
of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

Following up my telegram of this date in which I have said "When may I expect Cheque Eleven hundred dollars Regina Boarding School due Thirtieth June last?" I wish to explain that that amount was authorized by the J.D. & Co. for the purpose of a new Boarding School. The school was commenced early in June, but delayed by floods etc. On 25th June copy of contract was sent to the Commissioner & on 6th July an application for a part of the money. On 21st July (two weeks later) a request was received from the Commissioner for certified copy, which it took to the 5th August to get reply to postal facilities, not being particularly

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6369, file 763-5, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Good between here & Macleod. On the 16th August I received a letter from the Commissioner stating that the last day upon which payments were made was 31 July. I was afraid we would not get the money, but States had forwarded papers & had recommended payment.

I have been unfortunately forgetting to receive a cheque to cover the amount, but at present it has not arrived. The contractor is waiting for his money. The Church has already paid $1200-0-0 and we are not prepared to pay more at present. I beg therefore to appeal to you (the Bishop being abroad in England) to tell me what you can do.

The total cost of the building & heating is about $3600-0. It is difficult enough for us to find the $2500-0 which we expected to have to do without having to provide the $1100 which is anyway impossible.

Awaiting your reply,

Yours faithfully,
J.W. [Signature]

Dear Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your circular letter dealing with the danger of fire.

In reply I might state that the associated group of buildings which comprise the school proper and old and antiquated. It is, therefore, my duty to inform you that it is next to impossible to keep pails of water on hand as there is no provision to keep the water from freezing.

We have axes and fire extinguishers hung at the most convenient points, but, in view of the chemicals contained therein which has been on hand for a number of years, would respectfully solicit a further supply of these extinguishers from the Department.

Thanking you in anticipation,

Your obedient servant

(Sgd.) S. H. Middleton

Sir,

I am attaching a list of repairs requested by the principal of the C of E School for this agency.

I have gone over the building thoroughly and am convinced that the estimate is in no way excessive.

If it is the policy of the Department to repair the building to enable them to carry on till a new school is built I would recommend that a grant of $1000.00 be made to do this work, as I am convinced that the enclosed estimate is not sufficient to cover the cost as the prices are based on T.Eaton catalogue with no allowance for freight, further—all these repairs are urgently needed as the building in its present condition is a menace to the health of the children and the staff.

The labour is based on using ex-pupils where possible.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Ottawa, April 5, 1922.

Dear Canon Gould:

I am enclosing a list of repairs, forwarded by our agent, from the Principal of the Peigan C. of E. Boarding School.

This Department has not, in the past, held itself responsible for this type of work in connection with residential schools owned by church societies. Further, in view of the unsettled policy in regard to the future of the Church of England schools in Southern Alberta, I hesitate to make any comment. I am sorry to inform you that the Deputy Superintendent General is absent from the office, due to an injury.

I am of the opinion that the new principal of the Peigan Boarding School was under the impression that the Department of Indian Affairs was responsible for the building under his care.

Enclos.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. Canon S. Gould, M.D., D.C.L.,
General Secretary, Missionary Society,
Church of England in Canada,
131 Confederation Life Bldg.,

Sir:-

I have yours of the 28th ultimo, - your File No. 5/602-22 - enclosing a list of repairs requested by the principal of the Peigan C. of E. Boarding School.

I wish to inform you that this Department cannot hold itself responsible for the alterations and repairs needed for a building which is owned by the church authorities. I am forwarding to Canon Gould, General Secretary of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada, the details furnished by the principal.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

C. A. Arthur, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Brocket, Alta.
Dear Mr. Scott:

With regard to the Church of England School on the Peigan Reserve, this building is absolutely beyond repair, according to Inspector Christianson, and he tells me he hardly knows where to begin to make recommendations as to the repair of the building, as there is so much to be done to make it at all habitable. However, something must be done if the school is to remain open this winter, and what this should be is hard to say.

I would like, before making any definite recommendation to have an Inspector, or go myself and see what is required. It might be well however, for the Department to set aside an appropriation of money and when the Inspector goes over he could just authorize what he thought was absolutely necessary, keeping within the amount set aside by the Department for the purpose of repairing the School. Perhaps $1500.00 or $2000.00 would be sufficient.

Yours very truly,

W.M. GRAHAM,
Indian Commissioner.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
June 23rd, 1922.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, No. 406-14, regarding repairs which are required to the building at the Church of England Boarding School on the Piigan Reserve.

In reply I have to advise you that the Department will authorize an expenditure not to exceed $1500 in having the most urgent repairs required to this building completed. As suggested by you, the Inspector should visit the school and ascertain what repairs are the most urgent, and arrange to have the work done. Arrangements should also be made for the purchase of the material required, and for the labour in carrying out the work. Competitive prices should be obtained in the purchase of all material. The expenditure incurred should not exceed the above authorized amount.

These repairs should be completed, if possible, during the summer vacation, and can be carried out under the supervision of the Agent.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Dear Sir:

During my recent visit to the Victoria Home on the Pelican Reserve at Brocket, Alta., it gave me pleasure to observe the improvement made, since my previous visit, in the school building through repairs effected, especially to the floors and the walls. As practically all of these repairs were carried out by the School Staff, skilled workers being engaged for only one or two days on the roof, it was impossible for the staff to complete the painting which was authorized, and the paint provided, before the winter set in, but this will be undertaken by them during the coming Spring.

During my visit there, which took place on January 3 and 4, I found the building exceedingly cold, and our staff, now one of the best at any of our schools, still in need of a few inexpensive articles of equipment which would add greatly to their comfort and so that of the children. I talked the situation over with Mr. Arthur, the acting Indian Agent, and Mr. Roe, the acting Principal, and informed them that I would request your Department to come to our assistance in providing the following:

1. Storm windows for the central part of the main building. If these could be of the French pattern and fixed permanently on the inside, they would not only help to keep out the cold in winter, but the dust in summer.

2. A Bath-Room. It appeared to me that the porch over the rear entrance might be raised and made into a bath-room for the staff at comparatively little cost.

3. A New Well. The present well under the school building was made, I learned, simply by driving a pipe into the ground. The water appears to be very good, but it is not very plentiful and has at times to be supplemented from other sources. The installation of a bath, along with the
The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs.

provision of a better water supply for laundry purposes, would demand the sinking of a good well. This should not be very expensive, but great care would have to be taken in the selection of the spot, owing to the position occupied by some of the out buildings including the W.C.'s in years gone by.

4. A Force Pump.

5. A chemically sanitary closet for use in the winter months or in case of sickness.

6. A Cupboard for the Kitchen.

7. An upstairs verandah in the front of the building.

It was estimated that the total cost of providing all the above items would not exceed $1,000., and unless your Department is prepared to provide a new school to take the place of this one during the coming summer, or not later than next year, I shall be obliged if you will give the above items your earliest and most favourable consideration.

When provided they will not by any means render the building fit for occupation for any protracted period, but will enable our staff to carry on for a year or two at the most.

Believe me, Sir,

Yours very truly,

Mr. Scott:

Rev. Dr. Westgate has recently visited the Peigan C. of E. Boarding School, and he now informs the Department that more repairs are needed if it is the intention of the Department to make no provision for a new building within the next two or three years. This building was in very bad condition at the time of my visit in 1921, and the request of the Field Secretary is reasonable.

The alterations and equipment suggested are as follows:

1. Storm windows,
2. Staff bath room,
3. A new well,
4. Force pump,

No special provision has been made in the Main Estimates for this institution, but I believe funds could be found.

Sir,

The principal of the C.of E. school for this reserve has advised me that he has been instructed by the Rev. Dr. Westgate to apply for the building of a laundry for the use of the school, and has asked me to recommend that the department authorize the building of the same.

The letter to the Principal also states that an unofficial undertaking has been given that the department will spend $1000.00 for this purpose and advises the requisitioning of $1500.00 for this and other repairs to the school.

I have no information from the department as to what their policy is in regard to this school, but I have been informed from sources connected with the C.of E. that the building of a new school on this reserve for the C.of E. was under advisement and in all probability would be built in a very few years.

There is absolutely no question as to the need of a suitable laundry building for this school and it is only a question of how long this present building will remain in use.

For your information I would say that the present room used as a school room has cubic feet of air space for only fourteen or fifteen children and the average attendance is around thirty. This room also was built for a laundry but was converted into a school room while a suitable building for use as a school remains idle, situated only a few feet away from the present building and used at rare intervals as a church. I have been informed that the ownership of this church rests with the diocese of Calgary and for some obscure reason cannot be used as a school.

Looking at this from a business point of view I cannot recommend the expenditure between $1100.00 and $1200.00 for a new laundry building before an attempt has been made to acquire this church to use as a school room. This will effect a vast improvement in the sanitary conditions of the school.
by providing an increased amount of air space for the children and will at the same time provide a suitable laundry by the vacating of the present school room.

In this way the department will be saved what might prove a useless expenditure in a few years and improve the conditions now obtaining at this school.

Your obedient servant,

Indian agent.

The Secretary,
Dep't of Indian affairs.

Reverend Sir:

I have to refer to certain requests made upon the occasion of your last visit to Ottawa, in connection with the Peigan C. of E. Indian Boarding School. The most important matter brought to our attention was the provision of a small laundry and certain equipment for it.

I have to inform you that we have had some correspondence with our representative, in this connection, and he is of the opinion that the room used at present as a classroom is entirely too small for the present purposes. There is air space for but 15 children, and the Department understands the average attendance is nearly 30.

I have to request you to look into the possibility of utilizing the present school room as a laundry and making arrangements for the use of the chapel for classroom purposes. Our agent reports that this chapel, which is situated only a few feet from the present building, is only used at rare intervals as a church. He was informed that the chapel is under the control of the Diocesan authorities. I shall be pleased to learn whether, or not, arrangements can be made for the use of the chapel building as a classroom.

Later, the provision of certain laundry equipment can be undertaken. As you were informed, the Department is favourably disposed to ameliorate conditions at the Peigan C. of E. Boarding School; but it is considered that whatever buildings are at present available should be fully utilized before any construction is contemplated. This institution, as you are aware, cannot be carried on under the present conditions for any length of time, and the Department hesitates to make any major improvements to plant.

Dear Sir:

Re Laundry for the Piegan C. of E. Indian Boarding School.

In reply to your letter of July 25th #116-1-5, which awaited me on my return from a visit to our school at Hay River in the N.W.T. I beg to state—

1. Better Laundry facilities for our Piegan School are indispensably necessary.

2. That the Church which is situated by the school, being the property of the Diocese of Calgary and a consecrated building is not available for use as a class-room.

3. That the present class-room, although not as large as it should be for the purpose for which it is being used, may safely be utilized for that purpose for another year.

To build a new class-room which would be warm enough throughout the winter months would cost a great deal more than to build a Laundry which would not require to be heated every day and I would respectfully suggest that the best and most economical solution of the difficulty at this school is to have a new Laundry building erected and furnished with some inexpensive laundry equipment such as hand-worked washing machines, wringers, etc.
I have not had time since my return from the Far North to go carefully into the question of the cost, but I feel quite certain that it could be met by the sum of $1,500. This would enable the School authorities to erect a building of such a size and nature that it could be moved to the site of the new school when it has been provided on the Reserve and utilized as a work shop, wood shed or for some other useful purpose. As the building season is rapidly passing I shall be obliged if you will let me know if expenditure to this amount is authorized and if you will kindly instruct your agent on the Piegan Reserve to take the matter in hand at once.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.
Sept. 12, 1923.

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

The Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada and local Department representatives have drawn my attention to the extreme desirability of providing, without delay, laundry facilities at the Peigan C. of R. Indian Residential School, in southern Alberta. The buildings and equipment at this institution are quite unsatisfactory and I feel that we should grant the request for a laundry building.

It has been suggested that a small laundry be erected, by day labour, under the supervision of the Indian agent. The school staff and the older boys could assist. If this arrangement is made and the Department supplies the materials, the cost of the building itself will be in the neighborhood of $1200, and the equipment for it, some $300.

I should be pleased to have your authority to incur the expense. Funds can be found in the Appropriation for Indian Education.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Sir.— 

In reply to your No.116-1-5 of the 29th ultimo I would say that on re-reading your letter No. ditto of the 18th September and noting the last sentence, I realize that I have been guilty of a very grievous error in the method of paying the workmen at the construction of this building.

In extenuation I can only say that when this last mentioned letter was received we were just starting threshing on this reserve and as you are aware all the duties of a Farming Instructor devolve on the agent at this agency, I was absent from my office nearly all the time.

I am looking through the mail the major fact of proceeding at once with the building evidently overshadowed the minor one of the technicalities to be observed in obtaining the necessary specie with which to pay the craftsmen their wages.

I am extremely sorry that this blunder on my part has caused so much inconvenience and in assuring you that I shall guard against a repetition in the future of like errors, I trust you may be influenced to mitigate in a measure the severe penalty you have stated in your letter No 116-1-5 of the 29th ultimo, in the last sentence.

Herein is respectfully submitted a report of visit to Victoria Home Anglican I.B.S., Pelican Reserve.

As it is a most difficult task to keep things sanitary with such awful floors to scrub, I trust may be permitted to draw attention to some small improvements which are urgently required.

Floors... Dining-room (pupils)
Dormitories.
Girls and boys porches and lockers.
Girls washroom.

The Staff dining room, hall, stairway, and five staff bed rooms are very badly in need of paint.

If some suitable material were supplied to fill up holes in plastered walls also it would give the Staff a better chance to have things looking well.

There is great need as well for two new out-houses.

The principal has built three neat cupboards One for the prize goods in the class-room, another for medical supplies, another for clothes and I am confident if material were provided he would be able to put things in good shape.

I happened in one wash day and was delighted with the way the new laundry is enabling these children to get the very best kind of instruction for use in homes.
(I omitted to note the number of cows milking is four at present).

We have mentioned the need of some assistance to your agent who has promised to go over this school before we leave Reserve.

I trust it is not exceeding my privilege in including this matter of repairs in Nurses Report.

Respectfully submitted by,

Annie T. Brannon,
Travelling nurse.
Ottawa, October 11th, 1924.

Sir:

Miss Brandon, travelling nurse, in a report on a recent visit to the Peigan C. of E. Indian Residential School, states as follows:

"As it is a most difficult task to keep things sanitary with such awful floors to scrub, I trust I may be permitted to draw attention to some small improvements which are urgently required:

Floors ...... Dining-room (pupils)
Dormitories,
Girls' and boys' porches and lockers,
Girls' washroom.

The staff dining room, hall, stairway and five staff bedrooms are very badly in need of paint.

If some suitable material were supplied to fill up holes in plastered walls also it would give the staff a better chance to have things looking well.

There is great need as well for two new out-houses."

I have to request that you will report on each of the items referred to by the travelling nurse, stating what work is required to be done, the material necessary for the purpose and the approximate cost. You should also state whether, if any material is supplied, such as flooring, paint and other supplies, the school authorities could perform the labour required. Only the repairs considered absolutely necessary should be reported on, as, if authority is granted to undertake any repairs, it is not intended to incur any large expenditure.

Your early reply giving full information as asked for will oblige,

C. A. Arthur, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Brocket, Alta.

I also visited this school and found everything in fair shape. The children seemed to be in the best of health and the building was quite comfortable. The only repairs that are necessary to the building at the present time should be made to the children's dining-room and the porch. About 600 feet of flooring is required for this purpose.

The sum of $200.00 was authorized last summer by the Department for painting the school. The paint was purchased, but the Principal claimed he did not have time to get the work done this fall; he would do so, however, first thing in the spring. There was sufficient money left over after purchasing the paint to buy the flooring material that is necessary, and the work will be done by the staff.

I am of the opinion that both schools could have been painted outside this Fall, and I censured the Agent for not going on with this work as soon as the paint was purchased.

A New School on the Peigan Reserve to take the place of "Victoria Home." The existing building is old and so comfortless as to be all but uninhabitable. To undertake extensive repairs would be waste of money as these could never convert it into a modern educational institution.

Along with the erection of the main school building, provision should be made for securing not less than one section of land on the Reserve and also for the following buildings:

(a) Principal's residence (Separate from the School)
(b) Farmer's residence,
(c) Stock barn,
(d) Poultry house,
(e) Piggery,
(f) Implement shed,
(g) Granary.

It is estimated that a modern type of building could be established on a new site at a total cost not exceeding $35,000.00.

Dear Sir:

I regret to have to inform you that at 10 o'clock on Tuesday morning Nov. 16th, the small frame building used as a residence for the Principal at our Society's Peigan School was completely destroyed by fire with all the contents, including furniture, books, clothes, etc. The Principal estimates his loss at $500.00, none of which was covered by insurance. The Society's loss although considerably greater is covered by insurance to the extent of $500.00 only.

At the time of the fire the Rev. W. Barlow the Principal, was absent in Calgary having been asked to appear there by the Bishop of Calgary in order to receive his Lordship's license to officiate within his Diocese. He was advised by telegram of the fire and loss sustained, and immediately reported the same to me. As I left for Saskatoon, Onion Lake, and other points North and West very shortly after Mr. Barlow's message came to hand, I was unable to send you a written communication at that time.

The Principal received instructions to take up residence with his wife and daughter, in the main school building and as our Society has already made a special grant towards equipment, every effort will be make to continue the work under these conditions until the Spring
and summer of next year when it is hoped and expected that a complete new school building will be provided.

With regard to the cause of the fire the Principal states that, so far as he can make out, it must have commenced with the kitchen stove, but is unable to explain how. His wife being Head Matron and Boys' Supervisor on the staff was on duty in the main school building at the time, a distance of about 100 yards away, and his daughter was with her. Before the fire was discovered it had taken so strong a hold on the building that nothing could have saved it.

Regretting the loss sustained and the delay in furnishing you with this report,

I remain, Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

RE PEIGAN CHURCH OF ENGLAND SCHOOL.

Reverend Canon Gould called at the office this morning, and we discussed the plans of the new Peigan Church of England School. Canon Gould expressed himself as being favourable to the layout that has been provided for the Peigan Roman Catholic School with the following changes.

BASEMENT. Staff room at rear of building to be changed to dairy, and the staff dining room, adjacent to boys' recreation room to be changed to staff bedroom. A partition to be erected in the boys' recreation room in order to place the door leading to the boys' toilet in the corridor.

GROUND. Chapel to be removed to first floor, to the space now occupied by the Sisters' dormitory and community. Space on ground floor occupied by Chapel to be arranged to provide living quarters for Principal, and to consist of a bathroom, three bedrooms, dining room and living room, with direct entrance from the outside.

Dear Mr.Orr:-

Mr.P.W.Graham, of Moose Jaw, the contractor for
the Anglican School here, arrived on the 26th inst. and spent
two days in the locality before returning to Moose Jaw. While
here he staked out the school building, and let a sub-contract
for the taking out of the excavation for basement. He proposes
coming again, with his outfit, within a fortnight.

I took up with Mr.Graham the matter of his price
of $825.50 for the suggested change in studding from 2x4 to
2x6in outside walls and bearing partitions, and endeavoured
to get him to lower his price. He contends that Mr.Scanlon
is too low in quoting $430.00 for this change, and that his
price is based on the increase of 50% in the quantity of
studding, plates and girts in the walls affected; also extra
cost in transportation and setting; and in cost of wider
frames as quoted by his millwork people, and $38 extra for the
painting of same. However, he promised to check over his
figures, and see if it is possible to lower his quotation.

Regarding the proposed change in layout of floors,
Mr.Graham took with him the blue prints you sent me showing the
changes desired, and said he would wire me his quotation for
same within a day or two. He will also quote on the enlarged
coal bin, and extension to machinery room, at the same time. On
receiving these quotations I shall promptly advise you, and
await your instructions before giving orders for this work.

I do not see in the plans or specifications any
mention of a ceiling over the boiler room, and on mentioning
the subject to the contractors, they said they had not figured
on any ceiling for this room. I therefore deemed it best to
send you a wire, for in case of your wishing a laminated ceiling
such as you have specified elsewhere, the contractors wish to
include the necessary material in their lumber orders about to
be shipped. No doubt I shall hear from you promptly regarding this.
In the painting specifications provision does not seem to have been made for the painting of the metal ceilings throughout the school, and I should like you to let me know what is your wish in this respect. The contractors state that they have not included the painting of metal ceilings in their tenders.

I enclose herewith the drainage plan of the R.C. School submitted by Mr. Scanlon's sub-contractors for the plumbing and heating (Marsh & Scott, of Moose Jaw). Please mark what changes, if any, you require, and return it to me. You will note that some changes are shown in basement toilets, in accordance with the request of the Reverend Fathers, but these changes are not yet authorized, nor have any orders been given for them. I shall deal with these proposed changes, and a few others asked for, in a separate letter.

If you have any extra plans & specifications which you can spare, I should much like an extra set, which would save my carrying the one set backwards and forwards between the two jobs.

Mr. Scanlon is getting well ahead with his contract. The excavation is finished, the footing trenches dug, and all is in readiness for the pouring of concrete as soon as a repair part is received for the mixer. About 220 yds. of gravel are hauled, also a car of cement, and lumber, and the temporary buildings are erected. The weather has been hot and dry during the past month, and rain is needed for the filling out of the crops.

Your obedient servant

Report on Anglican School Peigan Reserve

Dear Sir:

Messrs. P.W. Graham & Sons, Ltd., of Moose Jaw, Sask., the contractors for the above mentioned school, do not seem to be hurrying themselves in carrying forward their contract.

On July 8th I wired them asking when their principal proposed arriving on the ground, to which telegram I received a reply stating that they were awaiting the receipt of their signed contract from Ottawa before commencing. As the contractor for the R.C. School was getting ahead, I wired again on the 22nd ult., and received a reply that Mr. P.W. Graham would arrive at Brocket on the 26th July. I met him at the station at 6 A.M. and took him to the Anglican site. He spent two days in the locality, and I helped him stake out the site of the building.

On 27th July he sublet the excavation to the same local man who had done similar work at the R.C. site. This work is reported to be completed, and there matters stand at present. Mr. Graham returned to Moose Jaw on 27th.

Sir:

With regard to the tar and gravel roofing specified for these schools, I am strongly of the opinion that they will not withstand the heavy winds to which this locality is subject, for the following reasons:

First, because there is not sufficient protection around the edges of the roof as shown on plan, which would result in wind damage before very long, and once a tar-and-gravel roof starts to go it is very difficult to hold it. The Architect shows a very good detail of a protection wall around the edge of the verandah roof, and if this detail (with slight modifications) were extended around the main roof, the weakness to which I refer would be overcome. I enclose a rough pencilled sketch of a roof finish that I think would meet the requirements. It is an adaptation of the veranda cornice and protection-wall prepared by the Architect, but with the two by fours carried right down and spiked to the rafters instead of resting on a plate, which change would give greater stability against the wind. This suggested change calls for considerably more woodwork, labour and sheet-metal than the cornice shown on plan, and the contractor asks $15.00 additional for making the change.

Secondly, the roofing itself as specified will prove too light to successfully resist the high winds for any length of time, and I would suggest, in addition to what is called for in the specifications, a heavy pouring of pitch, into which there should be imbedded a heavy coating of gravel. This might consist of 50 lbs. of pitch and 400 lbs. of gravel per square as a final finish, and we should thus get the necessary weight to withstand the drawing and buckling tendency of the strong prevailing winds, which as you know, often blow with almost cyclonic force in this Chinook district. The contractor asks $375.00 additional to add the extra finish in the manner described, or a total of $890 for the alterations mentioned in the present paragraph, and the extra pitch and gravel. I might mention that the contractor (Mr. Scanlan) is also of the opinion that unless the suggested changes in the roof are made, trouble from wind will develop in a short time. The extra sum asked by him for the additional labour and materials involved does not seem excessive.

As the work on the R.C. School is advancing steadily, it is desirable that as early a decision as possible be made regarding the suggested changes in the roof.

The changes suggested for the roof of the R.C. School will apply also to the Anglican School, although the latter building is not yet started except for the excavation for the basement.

I have the honour to be,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

Re Church of England Indian Residential School
Peigan Reserve, Brocket, Alta.

Your Telegram to hand, and in reply we beg to state the reason of delay on the above contract.

We were advised of acceptance of our tender by telegram on June 18th and confirmed by letter from your department on the 19th.

We received the signed contract on the 23rd July.

We started operations on July 26th, and had the excavations for basement completed by Aug 13th.

We received a telegram from Inspector Mr. E Gardner Smith to quote for increasing main studs for walls to 2 x 6 in lieu of 2 x 4, on June 22nd, and quoted on June 30th.

We visited Brocket again on July and took up the matter of changing studs to main building only, together with quotations for other structural changes on July 28th.

We wrote Mr. Smith for definite decision on these changes on Aug 6th and pointed out delay.

We received word by telegram authorising acceptance of changes on Aug 16th.

We then got in touch with our sub-contractors for Millwork and Lumber and instructed them to proceed with deliveries to suit the changes, which had been held up pending instructions.

Our general superintendent Reynolds left here on Aug 30th to rush the work to completion, but hit bad weather, in fact it took him until the 4th of Sept to get there by Road, and the storm lasted until Sept 27th.

We trust this explanation is satisfactory, and wish to express our regret that the job looks in bad shape at this date, but believe we can make up the lost time and are picking up a good gang of men, who have been scarce up to now.

Yours truly,

Upon his return from a recent visit to the Pelican Reserve, Inspector M. Christianson discussed with me certain changes which were deemed necessary in the Church of England School and I have in turn taken these matters up with Mr. E. Gardner Smith with a view to getting an estimate of the cost and beg to make the following recommendations:

(1) The provision of a sink in the Principal's kitchen which, installed complete with hot and cold water, waste and vent would cost $88.00 or with the addition of a deep apron, a drain-board and back all in one piece - $159.50.

I think the cost of this can be reduced by putting in a drain board of a less expensive type.

(2) The enlargement of the Staff Dining room in the basement, which however will entail only the cost of an extra window at a figure of $24.00.

(3) The placing of a range boiler in the kitchen of 80 gallon capacity installed complete, including connection to stove and with hot water line to the kitchen sink, at a cost of $143.00.

(4) Providing Burlap in the stairways, halls and corridors at a cost of $366.25, or if the rear corridor of the basement is omitted and I do not think it is necessary there, the cost will be reduced to $338.75. This with the baseboard and moulding will give a four foot protection to the walls.

I shall be glad to receive authority to incur the above named expenditures.

Mr. Gardner Smith reminds me that no provision is made in the Specifications for the painting of the metal ceilings in this school and has procured from the Contractor a price of $330.00 "To paint all metal ceilings and cornices in two coats, using best White Lead and pure Linseed oil". Report on Church of England School; Peigan Reserve

Dear Sir:

During the past month good progress has been maintained by the contractors, Messrs P.W. Graham & Sons, Ltd., of Moose Jaw, in the construction of the above school.

As previously reported, the contractors allowed two months to elapse before putting a crew to work, and with the exception of the excavation which they had sub-let, nothing was done at the job until the first part of September. During the past six weeks a fair sized crew has been employed under an efficient foreman, and the contractors seem to be making serious effort to make up for lost time.

The main building is now about closed in, and today the roofing sub-contractor is putting on the paper, tar and gravel. As authorized by the Department, we are making the roof heavier than originally called for. We are laying an extra ply of heavy roofing felt, and applying a heavy pouring of asphalt pitch, into which a large quantity of screened gravel is being embedded; and in addition to this we have carried up a protection wall 18" high around the edge of the roof, which will be flashed down over the turned-up roofing. By taking these precautions we should have a roof that will successfully withstand the heavy winds of the locality, and the sudden changes in climate.

On the whole there is not much ground for complaint over the quality of materials delivered. The lumber is largely spruce, supplied by McLaren Lumber Co. from their mills at Blairmore, Alta. I visited the mill in company with Inspector Christianson and Indian Agent Arthur, and looked over the stocks the Company proposed sending. I objected to some of the lumber, particularly the drop siding, and they promised to supply us with a better grade cut from special stock. It is impossible to get lumber from mountain mills entirely free from knots, but the drop siding is otherwise very good, and is the very best that can be procured from local sources. It is thoroughly seasoned, and I am hopeful that the knots will remain fast. This siding has all been primed by the painter, and is now
being put in place by the carpenters. The millwork is being supplied by the Cranbrook Sash & Door Co. and so far is proving satisfactory. The window frames were primed at the factory. Slight mistakes were made in some of the details but are being rectified.

The general framing work has been well done, and we have used every precaution in bracing the building at all points. Diagonal bracing has been placed in all corners on all floors, and at other points where helpful in making the building rigid. The sub-floors have all been laid diagonally, and all openings are being properly trussed.

The plumbing and heating sub-contractors (Snyder & Co. of Calgary) now have men at work, the basement drains are laid, and the roughing-in for plumbing fixtures is being done on all floors. I expect to make a water-test on Monday of the drains, stacks and vents. The heating boiler is now on the site, but has not yet been admitted to the building. The radiators are also here and have been distributed throughout the main building, and the steam-fitters are running their various lines. The pressure-tanks for water supply, and the hot water storage tank, are expected during the coming week, and the pumping plant is expected shortly. On this job we have a peculiar condition to take care of in consequence of having a "flowing well", but shall adopt means of controlling this surplus water and turn it to advantage.

The interior outside walls of main building have been sheeted with shiplap in readiness for the "house-line" covering, and this insulation should add materially to the warmth of the finished structure. I expect the electrician next week to lay his conduits for the wiring.

The rear extension is not yet framed. The concrete work is done, but owing to shortage of materials the framing is being deferred. Except for the footings, the chimney is not started.

The septic tank is completed, and sewer line laid. I checked over the levels, and had to order some correction work. I shall check this again before the tiles are covered.

The weather during past month has been favourable and practically no time has been lost during this period.

The contractors are dilatory in placing Fire Insurance and I notified them that unless the Policy asked for reaches me by Monday I would ask the Department to withhold further payment.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Construction.

DIARY FOR MONTH OF NOVEMBER 1926

1 Fine day. At R.C. job storm sash were being fitted & house line put on walls. At C.of E. job framing of partitions being done.

2 Fine day. At R.C. job the cornice was being painted & other work. At C.of E. job the sheeting of main roof was completed.

3 Fine day. At R.C. job fitting windows, lathing, wiring & hanging houseline. At C.of E. job sheathing of walls & erecting partitions.

4 Windy day. At C.of E. job tarring of concrete walls was done. A start was made pouring concre for settling tank. Plumbing & heating lines laid.

5 Windy day. At R.C. job 2 painters were giving 3rd coat to siding. At C.of E. job the work on tar-and-gravel roof commenced.

6 Cool day. At C.of E. job windows fitted & siding placed. The roofers cont'd their work but were hindered by wind. Plumbing work cont'd.

7 Fair day. I gave permission for roofing work to continue on Sunday. At C.of E. job by night this work on main roof was about finished.

8 Fine day. At R.C. job lathing cont'd. Sewer line covered in. At C.of E. job sheeting of walls cont'd. Plumbing & heating lines laid.

9 Fair day. At C.of E. job carpenters nailed up siding & inside sheeting. At R.C. job I conferred re placing of headwater, etc.

10 Fine day. At R.C. job painters were finishing cornice walls. At C.of E. job putting on sliding & fitting storm sash cont'd.

11 Fine day. Arrived in Calgary by early train. In art. I drove to Morley & attended official opening of new school. Inspected work.

12 Fine day. Spent the day in Calgary procuring prices & specs. of power lighting plants for Pelican schools. Took night train back.

13 Fine day. At C.of E. job the placing of siding cont'd. The plumbing & heating work cont'd. A good crew working at outbuildings.

14 Fair day. I attended to correspondence and accounts. Sunday.

15 Cool & cloudy. At R.C. job bricklayer started chimney. Plasterers arrived. Painters finishing siding. At C.of E. job siding erected.

16 Fine day. At C.of E. job wiring started. Siding erected. At R.C. job chimney being built. Lathing, painting, etc being done.

17 Fair day. At C.of E. job carpenters completing cornice & putting houseline on walls. Wiring of top floor being done.

18 Cold stormy day with snow. I drove to Macleod & spent some time in office of Maclean Lumber Co. helping straightening out bills.

19 Cold day. 10 below zero. Plastering at R.C. job halted by the cold. Bricklayer cont'd. Heating lines being run & other interior work.

20 Cold day. 10 below zero. I wrote W.M.G. re power & lighting plants. Plastering at R.C. school still stopped. Few men working at jobs.

21 Cold day. Spent the day at correspondence & accounts. Sunday. Inspector Christlanson arrived from Regina.

22 Milder day. Spent most of day at jobs conferring with Inn. C. particularly with reference to the outbuildings for both schools.

23 Cold again today. At R.C. job plastering resumed. Brickwork of chimney cont'd. Lathing & other interior work being done.

24 Cold & cutting. At R.C. job steam heat was turned on for 1st time at noon. 2 in one hour radiators were hot. Plastering cont'd.

25 Zero weather. At R.C. job the bldg. comfortably warm, and plastering and other interior work going on. At C.of E. job ceiling boards put on.

26 Cold zero weather. At C.of E. job framing of rear extension started. The cold weather retarding progress. Painters & electrician idle.

27 Zero weather continues. At C.of E. job framing of extension cont'd. Electrician & heating men at work again. Painter idle.

28 Clear cold day. Brickwork of chimney at R.C. school cont'd. A temporary extension above chimney to protect bricklayer from smoke.

29 Cold zero weather. At C.of E. job construction of rear extension cont'd. Heating work, plumbing & wiring done. Painter idle.

30 Cold day. Brick chimney at R.C. job finished except for concr. cap. Fire escanes being erected. Plastering, interior work cont'd.

At C.of E. job the work on rear extension cont'd. Electrician and plumber & heating men finishing their lines. Work hampered by cold.

Inspector of Construction

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit herewith my Time and Expense Accounts for the month of November for services performed on the Peigan Reserve, all of which I trust will be found in order.

There is one item on the list which, perhaps, calls for a special explanation. It is the item, dated Nov.11th, "Fare Calgary to Morley and return, $3.40". I went to Calgary on that date to procure data and prices on Power and Lighting Plants suitable for the Peigan Schools. I had received an invitation to attend the official opening of the Morley Indian School on the 11th, and as I wished to look the building over again, particularly with regard to the Fire Escapes and Plumbing, I decided to combine business with pleasure, and attend the opening ceremony. As the train connections did not suit, and would have detained me overnight, I hired a car in Calgary, and drove my wife and daughter to the school opening, returning to Calgary the same afternoon. The hiring of this car cost me $13.50, the receipt for which is attached to my November vouchers. Thinking, perhaps, that it might be deemed irregular if I charged the hiring of this car to the Department, I hesitated to do so, and after thinking it over I decided to charge only the actual train fare of $3.10, and the difference of $10.40 I am absorbing myself.

Trusting my action in this instance meets with the department's approval,

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Construction.

Dear Sir:

In a letter dated Brocket, Alta.,
February 16th, Mr. V. S. Lord, Principal of St. Cyprian School writes in part as follows:

"Some time ago Mr. Gardner Smith suggested to Commissioner Graham that on account of the high winds the high chimney at the new school ought to be anchored. The request was turned down. I was up there some days ago when the wind was moderately high, and the chimney was swaying visibly enough to crack the plaster on the wall at the junction between the frame and the brickwork, and one could feel, by putting a finger over the crack, the motion, about 1/16th of an inch. All chimneys are supposed to sway, but I am wondering whether these high winds do not create a situation out of the ordinary. It would not cost much to guy or anchor the chimney."

In view of the above information I shall be obliged if you will take whatever action you may consider necessary in this connection. As stated by the Principal, the cost of anchoring would not be very much and the additional strength which it would give to the chimney would be sufficient to make it secure against the strong winds which prevail in that part at times, and possibly prevent a collapse, which could not but be attended with very serious results.

Believe me Sir,

Dear Sir:

I beg to advise you that I have today issued a seventh Certificate, for $454.00 to Messrs P.W.Graham & Sons, Ltd., the general contractors for the above building, in payment of 90% of the contract price, and in full payment of authorized extras to date.

I enclose a copy of the contractors' 7th Progress Estimate, which shows how the amount of the Certificate is arrived at.

Regarding Item 31, I might explain that we have had an unique problem in the controlling of the flowing well, and in the utilization of the surplus water. The water rises to the top of the casing and overflows at the rate of about 120 gals per hour. Under pumping, the water level drops to about 50' below grade, and remains at that level even when we are pumping at the rate of 1200 gals. per hour. In order to provide against the flooding of the pumping room we found it necessary to "seal" the well,- that is to make the top of the well where the working head is placed absolutely water-tight. This required the welding of a flange to the top of the casing, and setting a concrete base about 18" above the floor level. A 2nd relief outlet is taken from the casing below the welded flange with two branches,-one to the trench outside the building leading to the barn water-trough; and the other to the room opposite the laundry to be used as a dairy, where we have placed a concrete vat, with overflow to a floor drain. The work was done by Mr.Snyder, the plumbing & heating sub-contractor, and the charge of $164.45 is for labour and material thus employed, and including 10% for the general contractor.

I think the other items are self-explanatory, but if further explanation is desired I shall be pleased to furnish it.

The general contract for this building is practically completed, just a few days' work remaining to be done, and which is more than offset by work performed additional to the contract. The contractor requests that his deposit security be now released, as he wishes to use his funds for other tenders. I promised to bring his request to your attention, and to recommend the return of his deposit. The fire insurance of $40,000.00 expires at the end of this month, by which date I expect to accept the building on behalf of the Department.

Re- St. Paul's School; Blood Reserve.

Dear Mr. Orr:

The matters pertaining to St. Paul's School which I discussed with you when in Ottawa consist as follows:

1. St. Paul's Sewage System discharges in a shallow ravine, where it forms a pool, and offensive odours reach the school and playground.

2. The well-water is strongly impregnated with deleterious matter resulting in the blocking of the cooling system of the power plant, and the hot water lines throughout the school. Also it cannot be used in the heating boilers, nor in the high-pressure steam boiler.

3. A heavy-gauge boiler breeching is needed before the next heating season.

4. The roof water from rear of school is discharging along the foundation walls, and will cause damage to the building.

Regarding Item No. 1, on the 28th instant I called at the school, and surveyed a line of drain from the present outlet of the sewer to a point 750' away, which when completed will transfer the pool to where it can no longer give offense. The cost of this work should not exceed $100.00. This will be for an open trench running straight with the ravine, instead of the present winding, sluggish course, and it will average about 2½' in depth.

Before making a recommendation dealing with the water supply, I am awaiting the receipt of a letter from Mr. Chene, Departmental Engineer, which he promised to send me, giving data, costs, etc., of an approved water-softening system adapted to the needs of the school. I am in daily expectation of Mr. Chene's letter.

I have asked Messrs Snyder & Co., of Calgary, for a quotation for supplying and installing a #10 gauge iron breeching, and insulating that portion of the laminated wood ceiling directly over the breeching. As soon as this is received, I will write you further on the subject.

Regarding the roof water which at present discharges along the foundation walls at the rear of the school, and which threatens very serious damage to the building, this has caused
much concern, and was more than anything else the reason for my going to Ottawa. Already we have foundation cracks resulting from this cause, and unless remedial measures are taken, I fear the ultimate ruining of this splendid building. I drew Commissioner Graham's attention to it time and again, but my letters and recommendations were consistently ignored, and the damage has been allowed to go on unchecked. Not being a technical man, I can only assume he did not appreciate the nature and extent of the threatening damage, nor my proposals for overcoming same. Early in the construction of the building I asked him for authority to conduct the water from the downspouts at rear of school (where the surrounding ground slopes to the building) by underground drains to discharge in the drain taking the laundry waste, which could have been done for $150.00 before the basement floors were laid, but he would not authorize the outlay. We now have to find less efficient and more expensive means for taking care of this water. At present after a heavy rain a miniature lake forms at rear of school, and gradually soaks away along the foundation walls, as already stated.

In order to take care of the roof water, I recommend that a length of iron sewer pipe be placed under each downspout, and then by means of vitrified tile drains, conduct the water to discharge in the main sewer beyond the septic tank. I hope within the next few days to send you a sketch of the proposed drains, with estimate of cost.

Indian Agent Pugh was unable to go to St. Paul's School the day I was there, having been called to Lethbridge to attend a police court trial, and he has asked me to return next Thursday so that I may point out to him my various proposals. He also wishes my advice regarding the proposed completing of the attic of the main building. I shall therefore go again to St. Paul's School on Thursday, after which I hope to be ready to report to you fully concerning the proposals outlined, with estimates of cost.

Your obedient servant

Dear Sir:

The general contract for this school was completed some weeks ago, and the school people moved into the new building on the 22nd of May.

Work additional to the general contract has since been going on, principally the installing of the extra millwork consisting of shelving, cupboards, lockers, tables, benches, pews, etc. The millwork people seemed an unaccountably long time in making delivery of the required materials, and about six weeks elapsed after the placing of the order and the arrival of the goods. This work is now completed.

The erection of the Garage was finished a day or two ago, this work being much delayed by the incessant rains.

The outbuildings, consisting of the barn, implement shed and poultry house, were completed some time ago, including the painting of them.

At present the extra chimney authorized for the Principal's kitchen is now being built, and should be completed in a day or so if weather permits. It is raining again today.

The anchoring of the main chimney is being deferred until the roads permit gravel being hauled for the concrete anchorages. This work can be done by local help.

The carrying of water for the use of the live stock to a point as near as possible to the barn will be undertaken when fine weather returns, and the digging of the trench will be done by Indian labour. It is my intention to utilize the water from the flowing well for this service.

I expect to issue the final Certificate to the contractor (Messrs P.W.Graham & Sons, Ltd) some time next week.

Last Tuesday the school was visited by Bishop Sherman, and accompanying clergy, and the school chapel was dedicated.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Construction.

Dear Sir:

I beg to advise you that I have issued today the Final Certificate, for $8377.10, to Messrs P.W. Graham & Sons Limited, in full payment for their contract and authorized extra in the erection of the above-mentioned school, and including also the 10% holdback of $5199.00 from previous requisitions, as the job progressed.

I enclose the contractors' complete account of work additional to the contract, stated at $14,925.79. I have gone over every item in this list, and have made reductions and deletions to the best of my ability, having regard to any fair claims made by the contractor but also keeping before me my duty to the Department, and have felt compelled to reduce the contractors' bill by $1246.14. By comparing the two columns "Charged" and "Allowed", you will readily see wherein I have amended the contractors' charges.

Having been notified by the Department that my appointment as Inspector of Construction, under the Civil Service Commission, would expire on June 30th, I made every effort to have all work completed, and accounts disposed of by that date. I notified Mr. P.W. Graham to come to Brocket so that we might go over the final accounts together, but he replied that he had got his data all completed, and was at the moment closely tied by a contract his firm were completing in his locality. I then wired him that I could not wait indefinitely, and that I should arrive at Moose Jaw on the 5th instant for the express purpose of having a final settlement made, and requested him to have everything in order. I arrived there on that day, and we spent several hours together going over his final bill. The account as approved by me represents a compromise; Mr. Graham agreeing to think he should receive much more, and I wondering if I was not somewhat exceeding my authority in passing as much as have done. I have used my best judgment, and acted conscientiously, and believe the Department has received fair value for each item I have approved.

I think most items on the list of Additional Work are self-explanatory, but shall make explanations regarding some of them, and shall gladly give any further information on request.

Item 38. The sheet-metal contractor said he had not figured on a service for the extension to the machinery room, and when I insisted that there should be one there, he charged extra for it. Also, a ventilator, with control damper, was placed in sky-light over the power-plant.

Item 39. The contractor states that in his tender for the change in floor lay-out, he only figured a "stoop" for the Principal's verandah. He showed me his actual costs of this extension, to which he has added 10%, bringing the cost to $617.00. It is an enclosed verandah similar to what was provided for the Principal at St. Paul's School, Cardston.

RE: St. Cyprian's School.

Dear Sir,

In a letter just received from the acting Principal of the St. Cyprian School, Brocket, Alberta he writes in part, as follows:

"As you know we have had some torrential rains here both in June and again last night and today. We have bailed out with a bucket, twice today, about 3 inches of water from the coal cellar and boiler room. The fault lies in the fact that the lowest point in the school draining system is below the basement floor, and not below the boiler room-floor level, which is about 4 ft. below the basement floor level. Could the Dept be approached re supplying some pumping device for such contingencies? Fortunately the plumbing contractor foresaw such a contingency and put in, surplus to specifications, an outlet in the wall of the boiler room which connects with the main drain, about 4ft above the boiler room floor level."

I shall be obliged if your department will kindly give the above suggestion prompt consideration and furnish the pump requested.
It seems to me, however that a permanently satisfactory remedy for the situation can only be provided by having the drain pipe lowered another 4 ft. from the basement floor level to the floor level of the boiler room and I trust that this action may be taken at the earliest convenience to your department.

Believe me Sir,

Yours very truly,

Field Secretary M.S.O.C.

Sir:

In directing the Secretary of the Indian & Eskimo Commission, S.C., I bring to your attention the matter of storm doors and windows at the St Cyprian C of E school on the Pelican Reserve.

There were no storm doors fitted to the fire escape doors in this building, whereas screen doors were fitted when the building was under construction. Since the spring of this year, when the doors were fitted, all the doors, outside and inside have shrunk about 4 inch. Thus, during exceedingly high winds, which are prevalent here in the winter, a great deal of cold air blows into the building through the doors and windows on the West side of the building. This is especially a cause of much discomfort to the Girls supervisor, whose room adjoins the girls' dormitory, and is the outlet to the fire escape, the door of which opens immediately into her room from the west. This same thing happens through the west door from The Principal's sitting room, and also in the girls Infirmary. Besides being inconvenient, such leakage is the cause of extra expenditure in fuel to keep the building warm. The shrinkage of the doors must be due, I think, to the fact that the lumber was partly green, or to the excessive dryness of the atmosphere here.

With regard to the storm windows all over the building. These fitted well when first put in in the spring, but now they are all too big. I have asked Mr Indian Agent Arthur to have a carpenter come and fit the windows, and he said he would, as it is a work for a mechanic, especially at the windows of the upper stories. So far this has not been done and we are advancing into the winter and expect bad weather any time.

I might also mention that I have reported to Commissioner Graham, the fact that the fire-escape doors open inwards in the building. Perhaps this could be remedied at the same time.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant

Dear Sir:

I beg to direct your attention to the need of telephone communication between the St. Cyprian School and the village of Brocket, about 3½ miles away. It would appear from information which the Acting Principal received from the local Indian Agent that an appropriation of $600.- was made available for this purpose during the past summer, but no authorization was given at that time, for the school management to proceed with the work of installation. The only action taken in the matter since then is set forth in the following extracts from the Acting Principal's letter just received, and dated Dec. 1st:

"The scheme which the Indian Agent had, whereby he was going to get the Indians to do the work if the schools fed them, fell through on account of failure, farm work, etc., and we have been marking time since then. The Agent states that the material cost about $400.- and that there is only $200.- left to buy another ½ mile of wire, and pay an expert to string it. He asks the school to haul the posts, dig the holes, and put the poles up. My objection to this is (1) This is no weather to dig holes, and frozen soil will not tamp, so that next summer the poles will lean all over the place. (2) We have only four big boys who could help with the work ......."

In the light of the above information it seems to me that the school management can not fairly be blamed for the failure to have this telephone communication established before the winter began, and that your Department should undertake all the work required in this connection, with the exception of the haulage of the posts. Whether this work can be undertaken before the spring, will depend on the
weather conditions which prevail in that part.

I beg to recommend, however, that instructions be forwarded to the Indian Agent to have the work completed as soon as favourable weather conditions obtain, and that the school management be not asked to render any further service beyond what I have mentioned in connection with the hauling of the posts.

Believe me, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 12th instant #116-1-5, concerning the erection of a telephone line from the St. Cyprian School to Brocket, and asking me for a report as to how the matter stands.

I regret to say that there has been a great deal of delay in the matter of getting the telephone lines to both the schools on the Peigan reserve erected, and Mr. Arthur must accept most of the responsibility for this, as he was instructed to purchase the necessary material and arrange for the erection of the lines with the assistance of the bigger boys at the schools. He did purchase the material and a voucher amounting to $416.03 covering same was received here on April 8th. On July 8th, Mr. Arthur wrote to this office asking to be furnished with an accountable cheque for the balance of the $600.00 authorized for this work, which was $183.97, and this was obtained from Ottawa and forwarded to him on July 28th. On August 24th, he was written to from this office, and asked to submit a voucher accounting for this money. To this he never replied and on November 2nd, he was again written to and to this he replied on the 16th. idem as follows,-

"I beg to say the advance for telephone line is still intact. The two principals of the schools were ready to commence operations building the lines when this storm arrived and at present it is almost impossible for them to do anything until the weather moderates."

From this you will see that he did not get this work started at all during the long summer and well on into the Fall and did not reply to letters that were sent to him. This is not the first time that Mr. Arthur has bungled matters, and as I have often said before-

Dear Mr. Graham,

I have the honour to report that during my recent trip to Alberta and while at the Peigan agency I called at the two residential schools on the reserve.

At the R.C. School everything was in first-class order, the children all looked well and things in general seemed to be progressing very favourably. The only trouble there was in connection with the water supply, the well having practically gone dry. There has been an abundance of water in this well and at the time it was drilled it was thought that there would be an unlimited supply. The impression was that sand or quicksand had cut off the supply and they were cleaning it out when I was there. As there is nothing on the file here concerning the matter it is probable that the water has come back into the well.

At the Anglican School everything seemed to be in fair shape also. The school was clean and tidy and matters in general seemed to be running along smoothly. When I was at Nobbema I received a wire from you instructing me to purchase five cows for the school, which I did. I may say that at the present time it is a very difficult matter to buy milk cows.

W. W. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Inspector Christianson's report on Peigan Schools.

I was in touch with most of the stockmen in Alberta and the only place I could find any cows was at the C.P.R. Farm at Strathmore. The cows which I bought are Holstein. They are not pedigreed; two of them are pure bred but have no papers and the other three are practically pure bred. All have passed the tuberculin test and two of them had just freshened, while the other three are due to freshen around the end of this month. The price paid for these cows was $125.00 each, which I consider very reasonable. They are from three to six years of age and if properly looked after will produce a lot of milk.

Regarding the telephone lines to the schools, the material was purchased last April with the understanding that whatever money was left over out of the amount of $600.00 could be used by the schools to assist in erecting the lines and that whatever labour could not be paid for the schools would perform with their own staff and the bigger boys. I outlined this both to the Principals and the Agent when I was there a year ago and instructions in writing to this effect were also sent by yourself. From that time on this matter was evidently dormant until it froze up last Fall, when several letters passed between yourself and the Agent. When I arrived there in January I found that the R.C. School had erected the poles for their part of the line, but were waiting for the Anglican School to start putting their end of the line in which commences at the agency, and I found that they had made no preparation whatever. I looked thoroughly into this matter, interviewed both Principals and threshed it out with Mr. Arthur, and the following is just what happened. From the time the material was purchased in April until some time in October no real effort was made by Mr. Arthur to have this work performed. He probably mentioned it once or twice to -the Principals-

the Principals, and some time in June he evidently thought of having the Indians make a bee and erect all the poles. This, however, he failed to do and nothing further was done in the matter until some time late in October. Father Levern immediately started in and he told me himself that he and the boys put up the poles in something like four days, so you can see it is no great task. The Principal of the Anglican School, however, did not go on with his part of the work. He evidently advised his Farming Instructor to start the work but the Farming Instructor refused. The matter was then taken up with the Commission and Dr. Westgate and the action of the Farming Instructor was upheld, so that as far as Mr. Lord was concerned his hands were tied. While I was there I got the work under way and the only extra cost will be for the purchase of a little wire if we happen to run short. I do not know how the work is progressing but I hope it will be finished before the end of the fiscal year. By the foregoing you will see that the reason for the delay in erecting the lines is the lack of interest shown by our Agent. If he had taken the lead the work would have been completed long ago, but he just simply sat back waiting for the others to commence.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,

Dear Sir:

I feel it necessary to bring to your notice certain needs with regard to the drainage and water plant at this school, with the request that you approach the Department to have them remedied.

1. From time to time bad drain smells seem to come up through sink or toilet traps, mostly in the basement, and percolate up through the building. There is no stoppage in the drains, but it seems to me as if bubbles form in the drain pipe and force themselves up through the traps. These smells are unhealthy and nauseating, and should be dealt with at once.

2. There is no valve to let the water out of the main water pressure tanks for cleaning purposes. The water pumped from the well at times contains much sediment and this is accumulating in the tanks. The tanks are placed horizontally one above the other, and when the water is low, the top tank being empty, the sediment flushed from the upper to the lower tank, makes the water very muddy which is forced through the pipes. A valve could be placed in the engine room for draining the tanks fairly easily. It also seems to me that a mistake was made in embedding some of the piping in concrete, making future repairs hard.

3. The return gasoline pipe from the engine to the underground gasoline tank is also embedded in the concrete of the engine room floor. Some time ago the coupling at the end of this pipe at the carburetor broke, and I had to make a temporary joint. There is no way of taking the pipe away so as to weld or solder it and it would be too dangerous to weld it as it is connected with the gas tank, with its inflammable fumes. This ought to be remedied.

4. When the school was being built I asked for the basement windows, especially those of the boys and girls play-rooms to be fitted with wire mesh screens, the same as at the Elk Horn school. These were not fitted, and their necessity has been proved to my satisfaction since. Would the Dept. fit these now, on all the basement windows.

I feel that the health of all the inmates of the school depend on the drain smells being remedied, and if it is bad now in the winter, it will be much worse in the summer.

(Sgd) Vivian S. Lord,
Principal

Sir:-

Replying to your letter No. 406-11A C.E. of the 31st ultimo I would say that in company with Mr. Stanley Pearson I have made a careful survey of the sewage system at the C.E. School here and we can find no fault with the workmanship of installation nor can we determine any cause for the alleged non-working of the plant.

There is a possibility of gas returning in small quantities should there be a temporary stoppage in the sewer pipe and a toilet in the upper part were tripped. This might give a small amount of gas at some of the outlets lower down in the building but a small amount of water run into the sink or other opening to the sewer would immediately remedy this.

Regarding the second complaint I find that at times there is quite a lot of sediment in the water of this well and as there was no provision made in the installation for cleaning the tanks the sediment has accumulated till now the water is always cloudy. A valve would be useless for this purpose but a hand hole in the end of the lower tank near the bottom would serve the purpose and I would recommend that this be done.

Regarding the gasoline pipe from the engine to the tank has been broken by what appears to be pure carelessness and I cannot see how the matter could be improved by exposing more of the pipe line. The plumber states that he can make a joint at a small cost with perfect safety and I have tried to impress on the staff the necessity of using ordinary care with this equipment.

As regards the breakage of the lower windows an enquiry elicits the information that during the last year only twelve lights were broken which amount does not seem to call for the expenditure of the amount necessary to protect these windows with coarse wire screen.

Dear Mr Scott:

Rev. Fr J.L. Levern O.M.I., Principal of Peigan Indian Residential School has brought to my attention a fact which is a cause of worry for him.

The case is that of the construction of a stable in connection with the new building. Work on this stable was started on the 17th inst and to quote the Principal's words: "this stable had to be built only where Commissioner Graham wished to have it. That means that an extra $100.00 had to be paid to afford us the great disadvantage of having the north end two feet above the ground and the south end one foot in the ground in such a way that there will always be a large hole of mud, snow or ice at the door of the stable. We have protested and protested again, but to no avail and finally Inspector Smith had to yield."

I do not understand the reason of Mr Graham's attitude in this and similar cases. I may add that the principals of our schools do not understand how the Commissioner can exercise such unlimited power over their schools and over the Indians at large. He seems to be the whole Department of Indian Affairs by himself. Really at times one would think that he considers himself as holding the monopoly of intelligence and judgment. Yet he should think that as a rule principals on Indian Schools are in a better position than himself to choose most suitable sites for outbuildings and most practical types of constructions and also that they as much at heart as himself the development and success of their respective institution.

For example, at Blood R.C. School and at Thunderchild's barns were built in spite of the repeated protests of
the principals. The result was in the case of Blood School that even in Mr Graham's estimation the barn is hardly fit to be used even as a granary and that the Commissioner had to promise another more substantial barn. At Thunderchild the barn was too small and unfinished. I could bring to your knowledge other facts all illustrating that our poor and devoted men in the field are simply the victims of a nearly tyrannical authority.

Really the situation is becoming every day more unbearable and I must admit to you that I am presently studying the most appropriate means to obtain a favorable change. May I be allowed to state that in my estimation such a change would be welcomed by the members of the other denominations interested in indian educational work and even by a large number of officers of the Indian Department.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Scott:

Your letter dated the 10th ultimo did not reach Brocket until the 25th, and in this connection I might add that the Ottawa postal stamp on the envelope is dated Nov. 24th.

With regard to the request of the Reverend Principal for a Garage, I enclose copies of correspondence which passed between me and the Indian Commissioner on this subject.

In the quotation originally given by Mr. Scallan he figured in matching the existing construction of the adjoining building. After receiving your letter I went into the matter with him again, and by making reducing the concrete wall from 13" to 8", and by making other structural changes, he is now able to quote a price of $620.00 instead of $879.00 previously quoted—a difference of $259.00. Even with the changes indicated we can have a very satisfactory Garage.

The entrance to the Garage would be from grade level, and not down into a basement as the Commissioner seemed to imagine. The location is suitable in every way, and without question such a Garage as is suggested would prove a great boon to the local people, particularly in wintry weather.

I might mention that the Principal of the Church of England school asked some time ago if it would be possible for them to have a heated Garage similarly attached to the building, but I informed the Principal of the Commissioner's reply to the R.C. request, and the matter was temporarily dropped.

With reference to the location of the new barn at the R.C. School, I do not think it was placed to the best advantage owing to there being a drop of 3' #7" in the ground in the 70' length of the barn. This will mean considerable additional cost in concrete, inside filling to build up the floor level, and in outside grading. I wired Regina suggesting that the position of the barn be changed to avoid these drawbacks, but it was refused. Apart from the additional cost, I do not think there is any serious ultimate detriment from the barn being placed where it is.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Dear Sir,

It is with the greatest pleasure that I come again to offer you my most sincere wishes for a merry Christmas and a happy new year, and to thank you again for your great kindness towards me.

It is with good reason indeed that, on the 29th of last August, you told us here "not to measure by the shortness of your visit the interest you take in our work". That same day, you kindly invited me also to write you and let you know about our little crop: it is the remembrance of these new tokens of sympathy joined to the numerous ones of the past that has prompted me to add a few lines to this letter, which I started with the only intention of fulfilling a duty of gratitude.

You will be surprised to hear that this crop, which looked so promising, has turned out a failure: the frost came before it was ripe; we did cut and thresh it and got 1765 bushels of wheat & 535 bus. of oats. I'm holding all the oats for the spring work and have sold the wheat, which was graded "feed wheat", and the returns are not even sufficient to pay my expenses: for instance, my threshing bill, which I just received from the Peigan Agency, amounts to $614.90, that is over 26¢ a bushel, for the oats as well as for the wheat!

I frankly admit that I feel somewhat disappointed, and the more so because I absolutely need two more teams of good horses and two sets of harness to put in the next crop -160 acres-, and have no way now
to make that purchase, which would cost about $550.00, viz. $400.00 for the horses and $150.00 for the harnesses.

Such is the reason why I have thought of showing you my situation by giving you these details, in the hope that you may see your way in granting me that amount,

Thanking you once more from my heart for all you have done for me, I remain, dear Sir,

Yours respectfully,

J. L. [Signature]
