Dear Mr Scott,

Please forgive me for not writing sooner before you asked me to inform you about regard to what news going on here.

In Lord Principal of the school here, a returned Veteran of the Canadian Corp, has just read a letter from the M.S.C telling him that his services will not be required after the end of January, upon statement made by you of the society, from information you have gathered when you visited this reserve last year, or what you have read from other sources.

In the first place may I say, whom some you the information, did not stick to facts, and I am afraid altogether to the truth.

The work at the school to my mind has been most satisfactory considering the difficulties it has had to contend with. This year they have grown and threshed 12 acres of wheat, 177 bushels, barley 19 acres 350 bushels, oats 45 acres 770 bushels, and put up all the hay and feed required for the stock, besides growing all the vegetables they need require.

They had 17 tons of potatoes, store & fencing inside rather small and, such a thing has not been done before in the history of the Mission, then considering the school land is mostly old farms, and nothing but a mass of stumps.

I think they have done remarkably well.

Your orders to the Indian Agent to please farmers have not been carried out.

I have been on most of the Reserves in Alberta, but nowhere have I seen such careful, hearty farmers as here.

I again repeat the school has done some considerable, but difficulties little which we have had to contend.

They have a very competent staff all working in harmony, and very good progress has been made, which will compare very favorably with any other school in the district.

The Indians all like Mr. Lord and trust him.

Yet some statement has been made to you upon which you have based your actions to ask for his removal (omitted).

I am afraid those statements are not founded on fact.

I will abstain from further comment, which I could make upon the state of affairs here, because I feel you will not be disposed to meet me, you having received information on one side only. I cannot help but feel that Mr. Lord is not getting a fair show, there are others who should be brought to terms, and while they are, you cannot expect any progress.

I maintain you do not know all the facts, and as what you know is one side only, you have taken your stand for his removal.

Constant claims for are not good either for the children or Indians.

I am not asking any favors for Mr. Lord, only that he be given a fair play.

I wish to add reasons for your action, and why you gave you the information so that he may have also satisfaction & peace or misfortune.

Thanking you for all your kind kindness,

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

During my recent visit (on January 29th) to the St. Cyprian School, I gave careful attention to the shrinkage in the wood work, especially in connection with the doors and windows, and satisfied myself that some immediate remedial action was required to add to the comfort of the staff and pupils, and to reduce our Society's heavy bill for fuel at this institution. The shrinkage to which I refer was too great to be remedied by the School management, and after reporting the situation to our Commission they instructed me to ask if your Department would kindly look into this important matter. I suggested to our Commission that as Mr. Gardner Smith, who was Inspector of Construction when this building was being erected, and was now discharging a similar duty at the new Blood hospital, his services might be available in this connection at but small expense to your Department, and the members authorized me to submit this suggestion to you for your consideration.

While writing, our Commission instructed me to direct your attention also to the need of another staff room. At the present time, the engineer and his wife are both filling staff appointments, the latter holding the position of Kitchen Matron. As she has been in our Society's service for many years but is now finding the work beyond her strength, our Commission have decided to appoint a younger person to this position. The lack of staff-room accommodation, however, presents a formidable difficulty, unless the "guest-room" be taken for this purpose, and our Commission feel that this should not be done if it can be avoided. They are of the opinion that as the School has been provided with a second class-room 15' x 30' on the first floor, the whole of which is not likely to be required at any time for class-room purposes, that a suitable staff-room could be partitioned off at one end of the same, and I was instructed to lay this suggestion before you. Beyond the installation of the partition...
And the provision of a doorway from the main corridor to the room, very little more would be required, and comparatively little expenditure involved.

Our Commission were of the opinion that your representative could report to you on this matter at the same time, as on the matter referred to above.

Further urgent requirements which I noted at this School were a shed for soft coal, and storage space for storm windows and mosquito screens. I found the screens stored in the granary, as there was no available space for them in the main School building, and our Commission instructed me to direct your attention to these two requirements also. In the opinion of our Commission the shed for the soft coal and the storage space for the storm sash and screens, could be combined in the one building.

I commend the above requirements to your earliest and most favourable consideration, and remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Sir:

During my recent visit to our Paigan School (St. Cyprian) my attention was again directed to the need of a coal shed for storing the coal required for the kitchen range. At the present time, this coal is stored in one end of the implement shed which is some distance from the main school building. This is very inconvenient in many ways, and I trust that your Department may be able to provide storage space for this coal in closer proximity to the main school building. An underground bin on the kitchen side of the basement might be made, with a hole in the top for dumping the coal in direct from the wagon or sleigh. This would necessitate the conversion of one of the windows on that side of the kitchen into a doorway.

I commend this need to your sympathetic consideration and trust that it may be made at an early date.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

The Principal of our St. Cyprian School on the Peigan Reserve has directed the attention of our Commission to the need of 400 ft. of piping for the purpose of irrigating the school garden, and I shall be obliged if you will authorize an expenditure not exceeding $50.00 to provide this piping with the necessary fittings.

Sir:

A request has been received from the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada, under whose auspices the St. Cyprian Indian Residential School is conducted, for approximately 400 feet of piping for the purpose of irrigating the school garden. It is stated that there is a flowing well and that the overflow could be used if piping were supplied to conduct this water to the garden.

I have to request that you will arrange for the purchase of the piping required and have same delivered at the school. Please take this matter up with the Principal and ascertain the quantity and size of the piping required. The total expenditure incurred should not exceed approximately $50. The purchase of the piping should receive your early attention.

After the purchase has been made, please forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Sir:-

I have to acknowledge your letter No. 116-1-5 of the 8th instant, advising me that the school authorities at the St. Cyprian Indian Residential School have recently engaged a new farm instructor, a married man, for whom it is suggested accommodation might be found in the second classroom in the school, and that an expenditure of about $80.00 might be incurred to divide this room into two to form bed and sitting rooms. I would not recommend this action. The change might be made and at a later date found inconvenient because the purpose for which it was effected might no longer exist. The room could be comfortably converted into two compartments by running a rod across the middle and providing curtains, if, indeed, it is necessary to make two compartments. I would not recommend the Department's giving consideration to the proposal of the school authorities.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo, requesting information regarding the construction of the Church of England and Roman Catholic Indian residential schools on the Peigan Reserve.

In reply I have to inform you that the information on our files shows that Messrs. P. W. Graham & Sons, of Moose Jaw, contractors for the St. Cyprian (Church of England) School, began work late in July, 1926. The contract appears to have been finished in May of the following year and the building taken over by the Department a month later. Mr. B. P. Scanlon, of Medicine Hat, contractor for the Sacred Heart (Roman Catholic) School, commenced work in July, 1926, and turned the completed building over to the Department in March, 1927.

Ottawa, March 2, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd ultimo, with reference to the providing of electric bells and an extension to the fire escapes at the St. Cyprian Indian Residential School.

Regarding the installation of electric bells, which, it is understood from the communication referred to by you from the Rev. Dr. Westgate, are to prevent access to the school dormitories when the exits to the fire escapes are kept locked from the outside, it is considered there is no reason why a suitable door lock could not be supplied - one where the outside knob refuses to turn the lock and the inside one opens freely. There are comparatively inexpensive sets of this kind on the market - for example, a lock of the Yale type. It is thought that this would be less expensive and just as suitable as an electric alarm bell, and you may arrange for the purchase of locks of the type mentioned for the doors leading to the fire escapes.

Regarding the extension of the fire escapes, I have to say that you may arrange to have a few feet added to each in order to overcome the necessity of the pupils having to pump the distance from the end of the present escapes. No unnecessary expenditure should be incurred for the purpose or in the purchase of the locks for the doors leading to the fire escapes. After this work has been carried out, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

Rev. Barlow, principal C of E School here reports the Lister Engine at the school requires a general overhaul and would like to have this done before school commences the first of September. Sir:

I beg to bring to your attention that sometime ago the Rev. Mr. Barlow called at the office and brought to my attention that the palliasses that were supplied to his school some years ago to be used as mattresses, were completely worn out. I informed him at the time that I would be down at the Peigan Agency and intended visiting the school and would look into the matter then. They were filled with straw and hay and answered the purpose of a mattresses but this is not very satisfactory. Sir,

I have a request from the principal of the Anglican School (St. Cyprian's) to have brick boxings placed around the stove pipes where they pass through the various partition walls at the school.

These walls are of lath & plaster construction, and the present insulation is the ordinary stove thimble, this considering the excessive high winds in the district, he does not consider sufficient protection, should the stove pipes get hot, in this I quite agree with him.

I have known a fire originate in the old school (Anglican) over on the Blood Reserve, during the time I was there, from a similar source.

PB CALGARY, ALTA., April 28th, 1934.

Sir:

I beg to bring to your attention that the Rev. Mr. Barlow, Principal of St. Syrian School at Brocket was in a few days ago and he informed me that they very nearly had a fire at the school a week or so ago, the cook having put too much coal in the cook-stove and left the dampers open. The pipes got red hot but fortunately no fire got started in the partitions through which the pipes run. He informed me that there are 6 different partitions at the school that pipes run through. For instance, the stove pipes run from the cook stove through one partition and then into the chimney.

The partitions are lath and plaster with an ordinary thimble and the stove pipes run through this thimble. Mr. Barlow is of the opinion that it would be safer if the holes in the partitions were made larger and brick put in with cement, and then the thimble through the bricks. He informs me that he can get this work done for $15.00 and of course it would only take a few bricks. It appears to me that this might afford greater protection from fire hazard. Mr. Orr, our Architect might have something better to suggest in the matter.

I might say that Mr. Barlow discharged the cook as this had happened before and she had been warned on several occasions to be very careful not to allow the stove-pipes to get too hot.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Christianson:

A request has been received, through the office of Mr. Lancaster, Indian Agent, Brocket, to have the batteries replaced at each of the Sacred Heart and St. Cyprian Indian Residential Schools. There are, I believe, 3 ready to go into the Anglican School now, but there are some cases of measles on the Reserve and the children will not be sent to the school until the epidemic is cleared up.

Mr. Lancaster advises me that the Anglican School has made a request for 12 additional mattresses. He did not give the size of these, but I shall get him to do this and inform the department.

Sir,

In reference to the Septic Tank at the Church of England school here. The principal reported their drain stopped up and on my getting Mr Pearson "Plumber" of Pincher Creek to investigate, it was found the trouble was in the Tank. On digging down six feet to the top of the tank, the plank top was found to be rotten, making it extremely dangerous for anyone to go down into the tank to make necessary repairs or investigate conditions. It was also found that an essential "T" Pipe in the tank had broken off and it will be necessary to replace it with a new one, also there will have to be a new top and I am enclosing Mr Pearson's Letter, stating what he would do the work for, and I would strongly recommend that a concrete top be installed, the difference in price would be only $35.00, but the job would be permanent and satisfactory.

Dear Sir:

During my visit to our Peigan School last September, I was strongly impressed by the need of a "pavilion," or shelter of some kind, especially for the girl pupils, on their playground. The Principal is endeavoring to get trees and hedges to grow around the main school building, but it will be sometime before his desire in this matter can be achieved, and even then, the shelter thus provided will scarcely meet the need I have mentioned.

It is the wish of the School management that the pupils should spend as much time as possible in the open air, but at present the open air periods are greatly curtailed by the strong winds which prevail in that part of the country, and I am convinced that a "pavilion" would be a very great help in extending these.

I have fully explained the situation to our Commission, and the members agreed to meet the cost of a comparatively small but substantial structure, if your Department would kindly prepare plans and specifications. It seems to me that a floor space of about 15' by 21', raised about 18" above the ground level, with walls boarded up to a height of say 4', and then open from there to the eave of the gable or cottage roof, would be sufficient, and if your architect will kindly prepare a plan and specifications I shall be deeply obliged.

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Sir,

In reply to your letter no. II6-I-5 of November 27th returning voucher No. 200 in favour of Stanley Pearson for $63.60, repairs to Kitchen Range at C of P School, I beg to say the water front in this big range was burst so that no hot water could be obtained, and as I considered this an emergency repair I did not wait to write the Department for authority. In regard the cost Mr. Pearson lives in Pincher Creek, the only plumber in town, a distance of 16 miles from the school, two and one half hours labour were expended on the Bake Oven, and the balance of time on the range which had the top warped so that it was necessary to cut all the bolts in order to get the old water from out and the new one in, also it was necessary to replace all the firebrick and cement in the firebox, and I think, under the circumstances, the charges are fair.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 19th instant, in which you report that the engines at the St. Cyprian and Sacred Heart Indian Residential Schools are in bad condition and require considerable repair.

You may have these engines put in good condition at as reasonable a cost as possible. The work should, of course, be done by a firm on the approved list. Please let me know as soon as you can the cost of this work, as we intend to take the amount from that provided in the current year's appropriation for these schools.

Until we know what the cost of repairing these machines will be, the Department will be unable to authorize any further expenditure for repairs and improvements at the two schools mentioned above.

Buildings & Grounds, (Cont'd),

The floors need paint: Rev. Mr. Barlow said he would requisition for material through the Agency office, and that they would do the work themselves.

Fire Escapes:

These are steel staircases -- one at each end of the building. I noticed there were no lights (electric) over same. Therefore in a rush on a dark night there is danger of missing the steps and falling, which would cause a congestion and danger of injury. The last lower flight on the West end -- girls' section -- lands on the roof of a porch (brick walls with flat roof). From the top of this the pupils have to jump to the ground, some seven feet, which is rather high for young children. There should be another stairway erected here: This could be raised by pulleys and weights to prevent ascending from the ground, and could be lowered when needed to descend. The East end -- boys' section -- has this extra flight.

Should a fire break out in the hallway of the main floor, or this become filled with smoke while the pupils are in the classrooms, the exit would have to be made through a window onto a porch (brick walls, flat roof) at the East end of the building; then jump to the ground. It would be better and safer if this ordinary two-piece lifting sash in the window were changed for a casement window. The cost of these alterations, the extra steel stairs at the girls' end, and electric lights over the fire escapes, would not be very high. I suggested to Mr. Barlow, who seems to be much concerned about it, that he place the matter before the Department through the Agent's office. I told him I would report on it as well.

Sir,

With reference to your letter No. II6-I-5 under date of the 5th instant, dealing with the repairs asked for the St. Cyprian's Indian Residential School on this Reserve, I am informed that there is $620.52 available, and that the Dept. intends to procure painting supplies & linoleum, also a Hay Rake out of this.

Today I was out to the school, and I find the old rake has been put in serviceable shape & working quite well; I would therefore ask that this be not replaced this year. The interior was all painted last year & they have a surplus of paint on hand, may this also be cancelled. The Linoleum asked I consider is a secondary consideration to protecting the outside of the School Building with paint from the elements.

I would therefore strongly urge that the above requests be allowed to stand over until next year, and the requisition herewith being submitted be given consideration, as the building is in very bad condition, devoid of paint in places, and the roof needs repairing as it is leaking.

It will be noted I have mentioned Mr V.D'Acoust of Pincher Creek for the labour, he painted Agency Buildings in 1936, and the work was entirely satisfactory.

I have the honour to be

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

T.W. Victor Webb,
Clerk in Charge.

Memorandum:

PURCHASING AGENT:

On July 5th, last, I forwarded you a purchase requisition for paint, varnish, linseed oil, turpentine, aluminum paint, brushes and inlaid linoleum for the St. Cyprian Indian Residential School, Brocket, Alberta. There is a limited amount available in our appropriation for repairs and improvements at this school, and the above paint and linoleum was intended for interior use. The acting Indian agent now advises me that he considers it would be better policy to expend the amount available this year in painting the exterior of the building and repairing the roof.

Under these circumstances, I should appreciate it if you would cancel our purchase requisition of July 5, 1938.

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Director.
Ottawa, July 19, 1938.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER:

Re: St. Cyprian Indian Residential School,
Peigan Indian Agency,
Electoral District of Macleod, Alberta.

In the current year's appropriation there is an amount of $600.00 available for repairs and improvements at the above mentioned school. The acting Indian agent reports that, after carefully considering what should be done at this school, the Principal and himself have decided the best method of expending the funds available would be to paint the exterior of the building and repair the roof. He has forwarded a statement of the paint, etc., that will be required and estimates the cost at $285.50.

To do the necessary work, the acting Indian agent states he has received a tender from Mr. V. D'Aoust, of Pincher Creek, who has quoted a price of $275.00. The agent considers that this is reasonable and he further advises that Mr. D'Aoust will do satisfactory work as he painted the agency buildings in 1936.

I should appreciate receiving the approval of the Honourable the Minister for painting the exterior of the St. Cyprian C. E. Residential School and, in that event, the purchase requisition should be forwarded to the Purchasing Agent.

Please advise me if you approve of our engaging Mr. D'Aoust to do the work.

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Director.

Dear Sir:-

Several weeks ago you requested us to advise you of the terms and conditions under which electric service could be provided to the Indian Agency at Brockett, and also to the Sacred Heart Indian School and to St. Cyprian School located respectively west and south-west of Brockett.

As you know, these loads are comparatively small and are located at considerable distances from our existing lines, the connection to Brockett requiring about 3 miles of transmission line with an additional 8 miles of line being required to serve the two above-mentioned schools. Thus the maintenance and depreciation costs on these lines would alone be a considerable item.

We would propose for this service the following:

Contract Term - To be 5 years.

Construction Cost - The customer to contribute the sum of $3500.00 if the service is to be extended to serve only the Indian Agency at Brockett, and an additional sum of $5500.00 if the service is to be extended to also serve the Sacred Heart and St. Cyprian Schools. The customer also to provide any required right-of-way over and through land over which the customer has ownership or control.

The Company to provide, construct, and maintain the necessary transmission lines, transformers, switches and other equipment necessary to bring energy to the above-mentioned localities together with the distribution system required to serve the several premises which constitute the Indian Agency at Brockett.

February 3rd, 1939.

Sir,

With reference to The St. Cyprian's Indian Residential School on this Reserve, I beg to report the Principal requests immediate repairs to their deep well pump.

This pump is placed in the flowing well and the cylinder is quite a depth from the surface, something is wrong with the leather valves, (I presume it is the leathers worn out & needing to be renewed). In order to repair this it will be necessary to have the plumber & his assistant come out from Pincher Creek, erect a tripod & necessary equipment to hoist it up. On enquiries I have made, the plumber informs me that it may be possible to pull up the rods with valves attached, instead of having to pull the whole string of pipes up. In the event of only the rods being pulled up, it will cost around $30.00 to $40.00 to repair it. If the whole assembly pipes & rods need to be pulled up it will cost considerably more.

MEMORANDUM

FROM
The Office of the Resident Architect
DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS
415 Public Building,
Calgary, Jan. 26th 1940

Sir:

Re: Chimney, St. Cyprian,
Peigan Reserve,
Brocket, Alberta.

In accordance with your request I visited the site of the above mentioned chimney in company with yourself on the 17th instant.

In view of my findings there and in accordance with information gained through careful study of the plans and specification for the above building, I beg to submit the following:

BEARING:
The calculated weight of the chimney is approximately 143000 lbs. The calculated area of the footings is 60 sq.ft. This gives a bearing pressure on the soil of 2400 lbs per sq.ft., approximately which is well within the allowable bearing load on the type of soil found in that locality.

STABILITY:
Allowing a wind pressure of 25 lbs. per sq.ft. of surface which is approximately equal to that of 80 mile per hour wind by calculation it is found that the total wind load on the exposed part of the chimney would be 4950 lbs. The overturning moment of such pressure would be 195500 foot lbs. The moment of the mass of the chimney and foundation are considerably more than three times this figure so from this point of view the structure is stable. Further, the resultant of a horizontal force of 4950 lbs and a vertical force of 143000 lbs. falls well within the middle third of the foundation and so the structure is stable.

GUY WIRES:
While it is unusual for masonry chimneys to be reinforced with guy wires I see no harm in leaving the wires as they stand. They are at present rather loose and I do not believe that even in a maximum wind would they be pulled taut. This is a good feature as if tautness occurred at any point during the swaying of the chimney it would cause an impact at the point where the wires are attached to the chimney and might have a damaging effect on masonry. However as they are they undoubtedly take some of the strain due to the wind and have a further stabilizing effect on the stack.

CONDITION OF THE MASONRY:
The brick work and mortar are for the most part in a very good state of repair. The flashing at the junction of the roof surface and the chimney is in need of renewing, most of it in fact is not in place at present. I would recommend that this be done immediately.

I would further recommend that the joints in the masonry in the space between the roof and the ceiling be raked out and repointed with a mortar mix made up as follows: To \( \frac{3}{4} \) parts of sand and one part of Portland cement add a small amount of water sufficient only to dampen the mix. Allow this mix to stand for from one and one-half to two hours or until the initial set is just taking place. At this time the mix should be re-tempered with water and 20% lime in the form of a paste added to it. Work this mix until it is plastic and use immediately. This will prevent more of the present mortar from falling out of the masonry joints.

I would also recommend that the sump pit located beside the kiln be cleaned out and that a concrete bottom be installed. At present there is no bottom to this sump and a good deal of water is lost into the subsoil structure below the foundations.

FINALLY: It is my considered opinion, in view of the above findings, that the chimney is at present thoroughly stable and in a very good state of repair and that if the above recommendations are carried out it presents no danger whatever to the building or to its occupants.

Regarding the small chimney on the south side of the main building, I would recommend that the loose bricks on top be removed in whole and that a cement cap be installed in their place.

Trusting that this is the information that you require, I am,

Yours truly,

Dear Sirs:

In November of 1939 two shipments made by us according to the enclosed invoices were apparently never settled for on account of the lack of freight bills proving delivery.

On a number of occasions this question has arisen due to the difficulty of having consignees forward the invoices with the receipted freight bills.

To overcome this difficulty we first of all had the receipted freight bills stapled to the invoices, expecting that in this way they would be forwarded without being separated. As this was not successful we finally resorted to having the freight bill glued to the invoice. Since this last device has been adopted we have found that the freight bills are forwarded to you and payments come through satisfactorily.

From the above explanation we think you will see that we have genuinely tried to have your instructions followed out, and the two invoices which date back to November, 1939 we believe are not settled for on account of their being issued before we adopted these later methods of insuring that the freight bill went to the agent and was forwarded to you.

Sir,

Re Peigan Agency Voucher No.261...$83.26 enclosed.

With reference to our Voucher No.261, for emergency repairs to the sewage system at the St. Cyprian's Indian Residential School located on this Reserve, this covers labour and material supplied by the local Pincher Creek plumber, cleaning out the septic tanks & the drainage pipes leading to the tanks from the school buildings.

These septic tanks were originally installed by Mr Pearson, when the school was built, and they have been operating for the last five years without attention, but owing to the large amount of refuse passing through, too much solids accumulated resulting in them clogging up. When this occurred the Principal Mr Barlow informed me that the toilets would not clear, it being an emergency I ordered Mr Pearson to work on the system immediately for the health & continued operation of the school. The ground was frozen, and about 5 feet of the surface earth has to be removed which covers the tank under the ground, both compartments were practically in solid formation, also part of the drain, minor repairs were needed & new wooden shafts from the ground surface to the top of tanks. In future I have requested Mr Barlow to have his staff clean out these tanks, spring and fall to prevent a repetition of this.

Incidentally the plumber was quite sick after working in the septic tank, from the effects of the gases.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Re Estimates, 1941-42. Page, S. St Cyprian's School.

In reference to our Estimates submitted last year for the Fiscal Year, 1941-42, and applying to the residential schools on this Reserve, I beg to enclose herewith a tender submitted to this office by Mr Maugham (Well driller) for the cleaning out of the well at St Cyprian's School.

I took Mr Maugham over to the school to see and find out the condition of this well; it is approximately 125 feet deep, flowing well, but has become silted up to within 40 feet of the surface; at present it is being used by disconnecting two lengths of pipe and leaving one length of 24 ft under the pump.

It is very important that this well be cleaned out as soon as possible, or it is quite likely to injure the well permanently. I would therefore ask for immediate attention while it is possible (the well drilling outfit being on the reserve) to proceed with the work. May I be advised by return airmail.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR

Surveys & Engineering Branch

Re: St. Cyprian Indian Residential School

The above residential school is in the Peigan Indian Agency at Brocket, Alberta. The Indian Agent is Mr. T.W.V. Webb.

Mr. Webb has reported as follows regarding the engine used for operating the electrical plant:

"The present engine Lister Brunson, 12 H.P. 2 cylinder gasoline is running alright, but for how long I cannot estimate; the last time it was overhauled I believe was in 1936, then the engineer reported that a new one should replace it when it needed another overhaul. This was the same engine type as the Sacred Heart School that we replaced with a Diesel. The proper way I would suggest is that a Department engineer from Banff be sent to give his report to the Department and if he thinks it advisable to replace, the Department would then have competent advice.

"There is this much that in view of the age of the engine, and the difficulty in getting repairs, also the fact of the Diesel using other fuel than gasoline, it might be advisable to replace this engine this year."
It would be appreciated if you could arrange to have your engineer visit this school at an early date and report fully regarding the condition of the present engine. If he recommends a new engine full particulars should be given regarding the type of engine required in order that we may supply the necessary details to the Purchasing Branch.

Director.
December 9, 1941.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle,
Re: Lighting Plant,
St. Cyprian Indian School, Brocket, Alta.

In reference to your memorandum of the 16th ultimo, an inspection was made on the 2nd instant by Mr. Snelson who was accompanied by Mr. Chadwick. It was found that the engine which was purchased in 1926, is now capable of operating the generator only to 50 per cent of its capacity. Needed repairs are estimated to cost $350.00 and include replacement of governor mechanism, reboiling cylinders and fitting two over-size pistons and rings, adjustment of crank shaft, tightening fly wheel and new spark plugs. This overhaul might extend the life of the unit for ten years.

A comparison of the estimated annual operating costs of the repaired unit and a new Diesel engine are as follows:

Present Gasoline Engine -
Annual fuel cost - $350.00
5% interest on repairs ($250.00) - 12.50
Total ------------------ $362.50

New Diesel Engine -
Annual fuel cost $80.00
5% interest on cost ($900.00) 45.00
Total ------------------ $125.00

This difference in favour of the latter will in ten years amount to $2,375.00.

In view of the foregoing and the fact that it will be difficult or probably impossible to get repairs for the gasoline engine, Mr. Snelson recommends that it be replaced with a Type 10-2 Lister Diesel Engine similar in every respect to the engine purchased for the Sacred Heart School at Brocket in 1939. This engine can be mounted on the same base as the old engine without alteration and operates at the same speed. It is hardly likely that any other type or make of engine could be direct-connected to the generator without considerable difficulty.

We------

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa,
Ontario.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6370, file 763-5, part 5)
We concur in Mr. Snelson's recommendation and suggest that tenders be invited for a type 10-2 Lister Diesel engine to be installed in the school at Brocket to replace the present engine. It is understood that Messrs. Bruce Robinson Electric, Limited, Calgary, are the Alberta representatives of the manufacturer and have such an engine in stock which can be delivered immediately on receipt of an order with priority authorization.

The cooling water tank 30" in diameter and 66" in height is in poor condition, being rusted through in places. It is recommended that it be replaced at the same time.

Respectfully submitted,

Chief Engineer.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

Re: Lighting Plant, St. Cyprian Indian School, Brocket, Alberta.

In reply to your memorandum of November 14th relative to the above, I am enclosing for your information copy of a memorandum from the Chief Engineer, Mr. Mills, dated December 9th, which is self-explanatory.

In view of the fact that it will be difficult, if not impossible, to get repairs for the gasoline engine now in use, and that the savings, which will be effected by the installation of a Diesel engine of the type recommended by Mr. Snelson, will be sufficient to pay for the cost of its installation for three years, Mr. Mills' recommendation to purchase such engine is concurred in.

It will be noted that the cost of the Diesel engine recommended may be about $900. The cost of the proposed new water tank will probably not be more than $30.

We should be pleased to be advised if you approve of the installation of a Diesel engine of the type recommended. If so, we will submit specifications for a complete job including supplying both engine and water tank and their installation. Bruce Robinson Electric, Limited, Calgary, which at present appears to be the only firm in a position to supply such an engine, can then be asked to quote a price upon these specifications.

Director.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR

Surveys & Engineering Branch

Re: Lighting plant, St. Cyprian Indian Residential School, Brocket, Alberta.

I am in receipt of your memorandum of December 15 in which you recommend the purchase of a new type 10-2 Lister Diesel engine. It is noted that you consider this can be purchased at a cost not exceeding $900.00.

Please submit specifications for a complete job including the supplying of both engine and water tank and their installation. As soon as we have this information the matter will be submitted to the Purchasing Branch.

Director.
Specifications for Diesel Engine and Cooling Water Tank
for St. Cyprian Indian Residential School, Brocket, Alberta.

One - Type 10-2 Lister Diesel Engine. The engine shall be tank cooled and shall be direct-connected to the 6 K.W. 550 R.P.M. generator now installed at the school.

One - Cylindrical Cooling Water Tank, Diameter 30 inches, height 70 inches.

The tank shall be constructed of 14 gauge galvanized iron, strengthened at the top with a rim or band of flat iron 1/4" x 1-1/2". The bottom of the tank shall be of 3/16" galvanized plate. If 14 gauge galvanized iron is not available 10 or 12 gauge may be substituted and if no galvanized iron is available, black iron of the same thickness may be substituted provided that after fabrication it is painted inside and outside with a good metal preservative paint such as Kem Kronik or equal.

The tank shall be tapped at a height of 3 inches above the bottom for a 2-inch outlet pipe and fitted with a 1½-inch drain plug with nipple and 1½-inch gate valve in the centre of the bottom. It shall also be tapped 5-inches below the top for a 2-inch inlet pipe. All 2-inch taps as above shall be fitted with removable plugs.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of October 27th regarding Diesel engine purchased for St. Cyprian school, I beg to advise that I have seen Mr Barlow in regard to the several points mentioned in your letter & he advises me that he did not take delivery of the engine as he figured that there would be someone along to instal the engine as was done at the other school & that there would be no object in handling the thing twice.

He knows nothing about the installation of such a machine himself & at the present time is without the services of an engineer & is attending to the heating plant himself & also doing his best with the lighting & pumping plant. This new engine weighs somewhere in the neighbourhood of eighteen hundred pounds & the installation of such an expensive piece of machinery is no job to be undertaken by any ordinary layman, especially at this time of year when the lights are on about seventeen hours a day & when a switch over would have to be done quickly & by experts with proper equipment to properly handle the job.

It was not my suggestion that the present engine be continued in use, but Mr. Barlow's. He says it was not his idea at all that a new engine be installed at this time & that he had suggested that they try to get along with the old engine, especially in times like these when money was so urgently needed in war work, but that if they were bound to have a new engine put in, he would like to have the old engine to operate a feed chopper in connection with his stock raising operations.

I might say that I had already had the machine hauled to the school & it is stored in a shed pending instructions from you & that there is no bill for storage against it.

As to the condition of the old engine, I don't know a thing about it. It might run for years & it was Mr Barlow's hope that it would at least serve for the duration.

In reply I beg to say that I phoned the Bruce Robinson Electric, Ltd., Calgary, who stated they had a man (or men) who could install Diesel engines. I asked them if they would quote me their rate (price) for labour: This is $1.25 per hour, an 8-hour day, plus expenses - transportation lodging and meals. They stated they could not give me the approximate time it would take to install the engine, unless they knew the type of engine to be installed: If it is to be a replacement, the same as that provided at the Sacred Heart School in 1939 or 1940 - (Ref. Dept. letter #116-1-5 dated Sept. 28, 1939) - it would be an easy matter, as it was just a case of lifting the old engine off the concrete base, and placing the new one thereon, using the same stay-bolts without alteration; also, the generator could be direct-connected, as on the old one, and there were no changes of pulleys to be made.

If another type of engine has been purchased, it may mean making a new concrete base, and this will mean an extra trip to allow the cement to set; also, will changes have to be made to the pumping pulleys, &c.?

I am enclosing herewith, for your information, copy of a letter received from the Bruce Robinson, Ltd., Service Department.

Your obedient servant,

C. Pant. Schmidt,

Calgary, November 11th, 1943.

Reverend Sir:

EX'D.

The following recommendation was made by the mechanic from Bruce Robinson Electric, Limited, Calgary, who installed the new diesel engine in your school during the month of September, last:

"We would recommend that this engine be checked over at least once every 6 months. Carbon should be removed and the valves checked. The Injector Nozzle should be cleaned and tested as per instruction book supplied with the plant."

This is work which can be done by the mechanic-engineer employed at the school. I understand that a mechanic-engineer has not been employed steadily at your school for some months; I think this is a big mistake; with the expensive machinery (equipment) installed for heating, lighting, pumping, laundry, etc., a competent mechanic should be employed steadily. Of course, it may be that a suitable man could not be found last summer.

I must ask you to please endeavour to get a mechanic as soon as possible, if you have not already done so.

I wish it understood, that we are aware that you have not been in charge, and have not lived at this school before September of this year.

This is to advise you that the man from Bruce, Robinson Electric was down here & installed the new engine at St Cyprian's school & everything there is now running smoothly.

He reported that two new pinion gears were required for the pump to replace two there now, which are rather badly worn.

I will check on these gears, getting the numbers &c. and will submit a requisition for them.

I would suggest in connection with this school & in view of the expensive nature of the machinery at the school, that pressure be brought to bear on the school authorities to provide a mechanic to properly care for the equipment. They used to have one, but they let him go over a year ago & since that time have been more or less of a nuisance, as they keep calling on me to send Mr McKinon up there to help them out & when he is doing that something else is being neglected.

He also recommends that both engines be checked each year, valves ground & cleaned &c. but no doubt he will make a full report to his company & you will be furnished with a copy of same.

J. F. Faunt.

I am late sending this but I was delayed and I am sorry. Now what is required there according to what Mr Greene showed me is a 14 foot set of steps with an hand railing on both sides and a cement slab at the foot about 24" x 48" and 5" thick to set foot of steps on.

This would make a good strong job. Hand rail could be bolted to these 2 x 4 uprights and the whole thing well painted. There would be 15 pieces 7" x 11" treads 31" long.

3 ½" x 4"

Frank Marshall

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

Re: Water Supply (well) at St. Cyprian's Indian Residential School, Peigan Indian Agency.

I beg to enclose herewith copy of letter received from Mr. A. McMillan, Indian Agent, re the above. Having nothing on file at this office regarding this well, I went to the School on the 21st instant while at the Agency, to look into the matter. Agent McMillan says that he cannot find anything on file at the Agency office re this well; Rev. B.S. Greene, Principal of the School, gave me the same answer.

The well is inside the building, in what is referred to as the Engine Room. The lighting plant, batteries, water pump and two pressure tanks are in this room.

I am told that this well was sunk in 1927, the year the School was built, by Mr. Ben Mills of Macleod, Alberta; that 6-inch casing was used for the first 80 feet; then this was reduced to 5-inch for the next 47 feet, which gives a total depth of 127 feet. I was also told that Mr. Mills says he does not remember these details.

This is an Artesian (flowing) well. The overflow is piped to stock-watering troughs in the barn-yard and pigery; another pipe inside the main building flows into a concrete tank near the kitchen. This is referred to as the "cooler tank" for milk cans, etc.; the overflow from this runs into the sewer pipe.

The seepage or leakage referred to by Mr. McMillan does not come through the boiler-room walls; it appears to come from underneath the floor in the boiler-room, and from the coal bin which adjoins same. These two floors are both on the same level, and are four or more feet below the basement floor level. A hole -- 12" x 24" x 14" deep -- has been cut out in the boiler-room, to catch this water, which is bailed with buckets and poured into a sewer-pipe connection, which is about three to four feet above the floor level. There is no sewerage trap in the floor of the boiler-room.

I am told that between two and three barrels of seepage water are bailed out each day; that the amount of seepage water is now less than it was a month ago; that water has been noticed on the coal bin floor for over a year; that the pressure of the overflow pipe is not as strong as it was before this seepage began to run into the boiler-room, about two months ago.

No one knows where this water comes from: It is thought that it might be from a perforated well casing, or pressure from the bottom of the well which soaked the soil outside the casing, and after years has found a passage near the surface, and seeps through the floor cracks and between the edge of the floor and boiler-room basement wall, which is not water-tight.

(OVER)

If the seepage becomes worse, it will be necessary to have someone on hand continually to look after the bailing. Otherwise there is danger of it getting under the steam heating boiler, and into the fire box.

As regards the dirty condition of the water, mentioned by Agent McMillan: I think that this is caused by dirt (silt) in the pressure tanks, as the water becomes clean after flowing through the taps for a few minutes.

I consider this matter quite serious and recommend that arrangements be made with the Surveys and Engineering Branch to have one of their engineers go to Brocket as soon as possible (immediately) to look into the matter.

C. Pantl Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

ENGINE

The pump, generator, and laundry machinery is run by a new Lister Diesel engine of two cylinders, generating twelve horsepower. This engine was installed in October, 1943. It is giving satisfactory service. The present cost per day for diesel oil runs around 30 cents. The 30" x 72" engine water cooling tank is in good condition.

GENERATOR

The generator is rated 55 Amperes @ 110 volts, 550 R.P.M.; as the present load reaches a peak of only 20 amperes when all lights are on, it will be apparent that there is ample reserve power in the generator.

The 56 Cell battery is in very good condition.

Two pressure tanks of 4' diam. x 10' long are placed horizontally, one directly above the other. They are connected and when the tanks are filled to a 40 P.S.I. pressure the upper tank contains approximately 80% air and 20% water, while the lower tank contains 100% water. These tanks are in good condition except that the 4" pipe cleanout of the upper tank leaks and should be re-threaded and possibly fitted with a new 4" cap. These tanks should be cleaned out.

The Pump Jack made by F. and W. Mfg. Co. of Kendalville, Indiana is in fair condition. Guides and gears are not much worn.

Fire Hoses. There are two 1½" fire hose valves with fire hoses attached on each of the four floors - eight 1½" firehose s in the building. The hoses look like they might leak in an emergency and should have a periodical test.

All Plumbing, Toilets, Baths, Sinks, etc., seem to be in serviceable condition.

The building as a whole seems in good condition; no serious sags or cracks apparent anywhere. However, it could do with paint both inside and out.

The Septic Tank was inspected. It should be cleaned out; this has not been done for some 5 years. It is, apparently structurally in good condition.

The Boiler is a Pascal portable straight draft made by the Port Arthur Ship Building Co. Ltd., Port Arthur, Ontario. is in satisfactory condition.

The Well is reported to be 100 feet deep. Water will flow out of the top of the drop pipe.

The Laundry is equipped with a rotary washer and a Centrifugal dryer. All ironing is done with sad irons heated on a stove.

No electrical appliances other than two small radios and one electric iron are connected to the electrical system.

March 23, 1945.

Re: Water Supply, St. Cyprian Indian Residential School near Bracken, Alberta.

In accordance with your request of the 15th instant Nelson made an inspection of the above school's water supply on March 21st.

About November First, 1944, water began coming through the boiler room floor through cracks along the wall of the well and through cracks throughout the middle of the well. Considerable quantities of water also seeped into the coal bin through breaks in the concrete floor and through cracks in the coal bin wall nearest the boiler.

This leakage ceased to such an extent that in January, 1945, only 8 barrels per day were dipped out of the boiler room floor.

On inspection very little leakage was found except from the charge of the pump, boiler, etc., but there is generally no bailing from the sump for leakage or flow fluctuates and is apparently not affected by changes in outside temperatures, nor does it increase by days of heavy water use as on laundry days.

When the pump is not in operation water flows out of the pipe (s) into a 12" pipe that flows down to the stock watering trough near the pig pens. The pipe is approximately 30" high by 72" long and contains milk, butter, etc. It was stated by Mr. Green, that the flow of water was excessive through the boiler room occurred — filled a large tank with the amount flowing into the boiler room.

The artesian flow which enters the tank and to the stock watering point below the pump head is said to occur through a crack in the wall of the building, other than water from the boiler room.

Dear Dr. Alderwood:

I am sorry to have to report that the Principal's apartment here makes a very unsatisfactory dwelling place and as the Indian Affairs Branch is making a lot of changes at this Agency for Mr. MacMillan, the new Indian Agent, I would suggest that the Commission press the Department for a separate residence for the School Principal.

I had hoped to put up with conditions as they are until after the war, but I am afraid they are too unsatisfactory for the following reasons;

1. Directly under the apartment the Girls' Day Room is situated and over the apartment are the work rooms, and in a frame building such as this the noise from these two departments is indescribable. We have tried to bear with this condition, but over a period of time it is gradually wearing us down. The baby is unable to get the required amount of sleep which also effects Mrs. Greene and myself. The children are continually told to keep quiet which is not fair to them or the staff. You will remember that the children were suppressed under the last Principal with very unsatisfactory results.

2. The apartment is very drafty and cold and no amount of steam will heat it in this windy climate. At times we have to close all the doors between the rooms and live in the kitchen. The three of us have had continual colds all winter and this over a period of time is unhealthy and another winter under these conditions is extremely unpleasant to contemplate.

3. The Principal's apartment takes up at least half of the main floor and as this space is badly required for school purposes it would be an advantage to the school if the Principal was housed in a separate building.

These conditions were pointed out to Bishop Ragg, when he was here and he will be able to give you more details when he visits Winnipeg next month.

With kindest regards,

Yours very sincerely,

I beg to advise further to the report of Mr. Snelson, Engineer, Banff, and the blue print you left with me at the Office for my information, I today went to Pincher Creek, and interviewed Mr. Fraser who is now in the dry goods business, and who looked over the blue print, and advised me to see his partner, Mr. Buchan.

I then went to the Plumber, Mr. Pearson, and found that Mr. Buchan was there, and discussed the whole matter with him and Mr. Pearson; I found that Mr. Buchan was busy and would be unable to do anything before July 1st, however he looked over the plans as did Mr. Pearson, and after considerable discussion the following is a resume of the discussion.

In discussing the main point was Paragraph 7 of Mr. Snelson's report, and after this paragraph had been looked over both parties, considered firstly, that the expense would be quite heavy, in sinking an inspection shaft as all the earth after the perpendicular portion of the shaft had been dug, would be rough digging, meaning that every bit of dirt would have to be removed through the original opening, and if any trouble was found around the outside of the pipe and grouting was necessary, this would be very difficult to do unless the water could be held back. Mr. Buchan advising me that if the water was coming up the inside between the earth and the casing it would be very difficult to grout if water was coming up in any quantity, as the cement would not have a chance to settle and harden, and if it did not then would mean that the casing would be there for keeps and could never be pulled out.

The Plumber, Mr. Pearson, suggested that as the possibility of after the inspection shaft has been dug that the leak may be hard to locate, as stated above it might be very expensive to take care of and might not be success, that the following means of finding cure of this which might be cheaper and more satisfactory; would be on the basis of the third suggestion in Para. 7 of Mr. Snelson's letter, that is place an electric automatic pump in the boiler room, enlarge the sump in depth, and connect the pump with the trap on the wall, thus allowing all the leakage to drain into the sump and when it gets to the level the Automatic switch could start the electric pump and discharge the water in the sump into the sewer thus letting it run away.

He also made a further suggestion that the well be cleaned out and after all the sand and mud has been cleaned out and the well is running over as it did originally, that two cisterns be built for the water to flow into below the level of the overflow into the dairy, so that when the water reaches the upper portion of the cisterns the overflow can then run into the Cooler in the Dairy. A small electric pump would then pump the water from the cistern into the Tanks and after using one cistern for a period of time closed off and the sand cleared out and while this is being done the other cistern can be of use. Mr. Pearson advises that when out checking the pump leather at this school one month ago, he found that what little damage done to the leathers was from sand. He also states that the sand passing through the pump is filling up the Tanks in the School where it is now being pumped to. The Pump and equipment which has only one;

(over)
length in the well is built for a well of 3 or four hundred feet, and is much too large for well which is almost a flowing well. He advises that when the Pump Leathers were checked the water was flowing into the Coller in the Dairy of its own accord.

It would seem from the opinions of the parties I have seen, that some thought should be given to the suggestion of the Automatic Electric Pump placed in the boiler room to keep the sump there cleaned out. This would take care of any danger of a large amount of water gathering in the Boiler Room.

With Mr. Buchan not available to work on an Inspection shaft till July 1st, but agreeable then to make the shaft and take care of the Bracing of the basement above the open hole, I would be glad if I could be advised if it is your wish to go ahead with the shaft, when I would contact Mr. Buchan for a tender for this work.

Mr. Bradley who you mentioned to me verbally has not come through this way yet, and the Mr. Fraser he mentioned is the partner in the Fraser & Buchan Contractors, Fincher Creek; but having purchased a Dry Goods store, leaves all the contracting business to Mr. Buchan.

Memorandum:

Report on Inspection of St. Cyprian Indian Residential School, June 26th, 1945.

On the 22nd instant Mr. C.P. Schmidt, requested by telephone that I visit the St. Cyprian School and the Brocket Agency, and while there contact Mr. J. Maughan, well driller, with regard to having him clean the sand out of the well at the St. Cyprian School, while he was in that immediate vicinity; also to contact Mr. Pearson, plumber of Pincher Creek with reference to repairs to pressure tank blow off and the possible installation of a sump pump in the boiler room of the St. Cyprian School.

I met Mr. Maughan in the Queens Hotel, Macleod, on the 25th instant. He agreed to clean the well for the sum of $100.00 to $180.00 depending on difficulties encountered. This agreement was contingent upon Mr. Maughan getting authority to clean the well before June 28th. On the 26th instant, Mr. Schmidt advised me that he had wired Mr. McMillan, Indian Agent at Brocket, Alberta, authority to arrange with Mr. Maughan for the immediate cleaning of the well.

I advised Mr. Schmidt that I would recommend, for the present, that the well be cleaned; such cleaning should provide free enough passage for the water up the pipe, so that there would be very little, if any, leakage coming up along the outside of the casing. If such proves to be true, then all that may be necessary for the future, will be the installation of a small sump pump to keep any seepage out of the boiler room. This pump can be installed for approximately $100.00 including labour and material.

Whether or not it will be necessary to sink an inspection shaft under the pump house to determine position or source of leak will depend on conditions as observed after the well has been cleaned. The repairs to the blow off from the upper pressure tank will cost approximately $20.00 for a new 4" nipple to be welded to the tank.

I attach hereto a stenographer's memo. of my report to Mr. Schmidt on the afternoon of June 26th.

I asked Mr. Schmidt to advise me a day or two in advance so that I could be present when the well was cleaned.

Inspection of St. Cyprian Indian School near Brocket, Alberta, August 8th and 9th, 1945.

Mr. William Maclean, well driller of Lethbridge, arrived at the St. Cyprian Indian Residential School at 11:00 AM, August 8th, with a well drilling rig pulled by a large Ford truck.

The rig was set up against the outside wall of the pump-house, with the derrick inclined (by jacking up the front end of the rig chassis) from the perpendicular sufficiently to permit of the drill line dropping from the head block through existing openings in the roof and ceiling of the pump-house, to the exposed top of well casing in a cement block on the pump-house floor. The pump head and jack were removed from the top of the casing, and a length of 30" pump barrel and cylinder and 8 feet of 4" pipe below the cylinder, pulled out of the well casing.

The boiler was then run several times and cleaned some sand and silt out of the well to a depth of 68 feet below the outside ground level. At this depth some obstruction prevented the boiler from running any deeper in the well. The boiler was then removed and a drill string run into the well for the purpose of loosening up the obstruction, supposed to be hard pan. The drilling was continued for some twenty minutes without any footage whatever being gained. The drill was just bouncing back from some very solid obstruction. The driller was of the opinion that this obstruction was a break in the well casing, as he had experienced no difficulty whatever in running the boiler to the bottom of the well, 180 feet, when he had cleaned this well in 1942. Mr. Maclean stated that it was impossible to attempt to drill further as the drill was getting stuck in the distorted casing and that further drilling might result in losing the artesian flow of the well.

The flow of the well was apparently the same after drilling operations as before, but, in the opinion of the school caretaker, not so much as after the well was cleaned in 1942. The 38 feet of mud and sand remaining in the casing below the break at 68 feet would certainly reduce the flow of the well from what it was with a clean hole. I would, therefore, recommend that nothing further be done to this well for the present and that a sump pump be installed at once in the boiler room.

Sir,

Re: St Cyprians Indian Residential Well and Water Supply.

I beg to make the following report on the well at the St Cyprians Anglican School Peigan Agency Brocket.

History Since Cleaning out

Since this well was cleaned out early in August, it has given fair satisfaction, until early in November when the well stopped pumping. The Farm Instructor gave the Pump Rod a blow with a hammer releasing the plunger which was seized and the pump again started to pull water. This carried on till the end of November. As it seized, this again was released and pumped for a few days. On December 1st the plunger again seized and the Plumber again sent out his man to look it over, the leathers were badly cut with sand but after putting it together with new Leathers it pumped the tank full to a Forty Pound Pressure; On the morning of the 2nd it again would not pump and the Plumber S Pearson came out with his man, and after considerable work again got the Pump going again this time it only worked for a short period, and then seized again, the spent the balance of the day trying to take the Pump rods out but to no avail, they reported to me that night and I contacted Mr W Maughan of Lethbridge who cleaned out the well, and he said he would come out with his truck and five ton wench, this he did on the morning of the 3rd, and with the full power of the winch, and four men on a cropper we were able to pull the Pump rods which were unmovable owing to the plunger with leathers being tightly seized by sand.

Work done.

After pulling the Pump rods and plunger and getting the top valve out, I held a discussion with Mr Pearson and Mr Maughan, regarding the best way to continue a flow of water into the School through the tanks. It was decided the only way to get water through to the tanks would be an Electric Pump of a small type, which would go into the Four Inch Pump Casing, and pump from the surface of the well, this would take a longer time to pump but would not agitate the water in the well thus keeping the sand from being stirred up and clogging. This is being installed today and a further report on results will be made.

Condition of Well.

Mr Maughan's opinion.

The check up of this well since I cleaned it out early in August, and made my report to the Surveys and Engineering Branch at Banff Alberta in which I stated that the well would never be satisfactory and that the casing was dotted at 55 feet, and broken off, on this visit a Qrench attached to string was dropped down the well and the lowest it would go was 78 feet.

Copies Inspector C P Schmidt Calgary, Surveys & Engineering Branch Banff.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6370, file 763-5, part 6)
Mr Maughan's Opinion (Contd).

He advises that the large pump now in use will never be able to work owing to the strong agitation causing the sand and mud to come up in the casing, damaging the leather on the plunger in one pumping. The water still trickles over the casing and runs into the Dairy and Barns. In mentioning the advisability of drilling a new well, he stated that the old well would have to be cemented off; this he figured would force the cement up outside the casing and would gradually work up through the cracks in the Boiler room racks closing them off. I understand that the only outfit who can do this is Halliburton Bros Turner Valley, and their price would almost be prohibitive.

Mr Pearson's Opinion.

Mr Pearson who today completed the installation of the Electric Pump, placed the one inch suction in the well to the depth of Ten Feet, but after a trial run of one hour found it was still bringing up sand and silt, and the water was dirty. He cut this pipe to five feet and again installed the Pump with the five feet of suction pipe, and tried pumping for approximately two hours, when it was found that the water coming through the Pump into the tanks was clear, while at the School I watched the Pump running and saw that the water in the well had only receded two feet from the surface of the well, thus leaving a depth of three feet of suction pipe continuously under water, this never varied for a period of three to four hours had not changed. Mr Pearson is satisfied that this is the most economic manner to provide water for the School, and is opposed to the drilling of a new well, which if done might have the same Sandy bottom as we have in the present well. As this well now stands it would be possible to keep a pressure of 35 lbs, with an automatic start at twenty-three lbs. This of course would give a pressure strong enough for the use of the fire Hoses, but would not be able to keep the volume up for use in the case of fires, but should keep the School on a very satisfactory basis with the overflow to the Barn and Dairy running when the pump is not working. Mr Pearson also advised me that a year after the well was drilled some 19 years ago, he was called to clean the sand out of the tanks.

Agent's Comment.

I kept in close contact all the time this work was being done, and I feel on the results to date that Mr Pearson is correct in his opinion, that expenditure on a new well would be very foolish.

I would recommend that the present set up, as completed be left as it is till Spring if it proves a success, when the whole system as at present, and future action be placed in the hands of an Engineer of the Waters Branch, this will give time to see the results of the installation of the Electric Pump, and would also be early enough if any change of policy was considered, to have the work done during the summer holidays when the school is almost empty. As this work was a necessary emergency, owing to the time of year, and the risk of accidents to equipment from lack of water in the Boilers, I trust that the Dept will concur in the action I have Taken. Vouchers for work done will be forwarded as soon as received.

Indian Agent.

Log December 6th. Accompanied by Mr Mc Kinnon I went to the School and made a check on the way the new installation was working and found the School using the maximum amount of water they would at any time with the Laundries and baths being used and found the pump was supplying.
was supplying all the water needed and maintaining normal pressure, this would mean that the change over was handling the water question of the School satisfactorily. The water coming through the tap at the pump was perfectly clear from sand or silt; also the water coming through the taps in the School was still dirty most likely from the silt laying in the mains. The Principal advised me that the water was clearer than at any time during his regime.

AGENT'S REPORT FOR THE QUARTER ENDING DECEMBER 31st, 1945.

St Cyprians School.

This School has run into considerable trouble during this quarter and as things were slipping I kept a much closer check on this school than the other.

The Principal who last year gave hope of making a very good success both with the School work and the Manual Training, shortly after school opened began to show a lack of interest in the work, and the school as a whole showed the results. For a considerable time during this quarter it was found that he was very seldom available on my visits, this culminated with my taking this matter up with the Secretary of the Synod who happened to call at my home, when I found that his private life had forced the executive of the Synod to have him up before them, this they did and while there tended his resignation and left the School the following day, he was however replaced by Chas S Middleton from Cardston who took over and is given every satisfaction.

During this quarter the well again gave very serious results, and on going to the School with the plumber, I found the Tanks almost empty, and no action being taken as the Farm Instructor who acts as Engineer was on leave. Mr Pearson along with Mr Maughan cleaned out the well plunger, and after considerable discussion decided it would be best to install an electric pump with a very short length of pipe this has proved successful to date.

A complete report has gone forward on this.

Anthony McMillan,
Indian Agent.

On my visit to the Peigan Agency in May, the Agent and the Principal of St. Cyprian's Anglican Residential School had me look over the Church of England Mission House, now vacant, which was formerly occupied by the late Rev. Canon Haynes.

This is a well-built, 6-roomed cottage, and is still in reasonably good condition.

It is understood that Dr. Alderwood, Secretary of the M.S.C.C., wished to have this moved from its present location onto the School property, where it might be used as a residence for either the Principal or the Farmer.

On reference to the Estimates of expenditures for education on this Reserve, it is noted that the sum of $6,000.00 was inserted on Page 11, for the erection of a residence at St. Cyprian's.

Sir,

I beg to advise that further to my Night Lettergram of the 23rd inst., I would report as follows on the loss of the Horse and Cattle Barn by fire at the St Cyprians Anglican School.

At approximately twenty minutes past three o'clock on the afternoon of the 23rd inst., I received a phone call from the Principal of the above school advising me that the barn was on fire; Accompanied by the Clerk I spread the alarm around Brocket; and left with a carload of Indians for the School; When we arrived there around 3.25 P.M., the Barn was a mass of flames and the roof had just fallen in, a large number of Indians had arrived from the threshing crew and surrounding farms, but were only able to help in keeping the other buildings wet so that a spark would not start some other fire. The fire was aggravated by the loft of the barn being full of hay, approximately 80 tons.

As soon as I arrived I checked with the Principal, on the boys to make sure none were missing, the only children playing in the school yard some distance away were the small tots. On the information of the Farm Instructor Engineer no one had been in the barn since early morning, and the fire was first noticed by him, when he saw a funnel of smoke come out through the cupola on the top of the Hip roofed barn, he rushed to the barn, and opened the door when he was met by a cloud of smoke, following the flames, he was able to save one horse, but four two months old calves perished in the flames. The people who gathered there, helped in the saving of the other out buildings, and also from the sparks causing a prairie fire.

I would gauge the wind blowing at the time to be between 30 and 40 mile an hour wind, and as this kept up all night, I returned to the school at 6 P.M. and waited until 11 P.M. for the fire to get down to a reasonable size, it taking quite a period for the hay to burn down. When I left the embers were still burning, but with very little flame, and the principal had men on guard duty all night. We have one thing to be thankful for and that is that the wind was in the west, with no chance of sparks falling on the school.

I discussed the question of the Milk herd with the Principal, this can be temporary placed in the long Implement shed, until it is possible to replace the barn; In this connection if it is the best's wish to rebuild lumber for completion will be hard to get, however a barn could be put up as a shell completed when finished lumber is available. This however can be taken up after the debris has been cleared up and the state of the Foundation is inspected.

I also discussed the question of Feed with Mr Cole they having lost their whole winters feed, and I offered him a small stack of 1½? old hay at the C.I. Ranch, which we do not intend to use, I can also if it is the wish of the Branch spare him some from my surplus from last year. I also gathered the Indians together and suggested to them that they put on a bee and put up as much possible before the weather breaks.

The children were allowed to go home for
for twenty-four hours in case of a change of wind causing the sparks to travel over the direction of the school.

The older boys were kept so that help would be available if needed.

After looking over the situation and discussing it with the Principal Mr Cole, and Mr Irwin it would look apparent that the fire was caused by combustion in the loft; I checked with Mr Irwin re the lighting of the barn, but found that during the day the main switch had been pulled, and he was satisfied that there was no possible chance of a short circuit. The children were all in their class rooms, except for a few small boys and girls playing in the grounds close to the school.

I would be glad to have the Branch's instructions as to whether immediate action will be taken to replace this building, or whether a temporary structure will be built to house the milk cows. If such action is thought off, nails are practically not purchasable, and it would be necessary if the Branch can locate any to have them shipped out from the East. At present building in this District is completely stopped through lack of nails.

This completes my report on the fire which I am very sorry to have to report.

Anthony McCullough
Indian Agent.

On the information of the Farm Instructor Engineer no one had been in the barn since early morning and the fire was first noticed by him, when he saw a funnel of smoke come out through the window on the top of the Hip roofed barn, he rushed to the barn, and opened the door when he was met by a cloud of smoke, followed by flames, he was able to save one horse, but four two months old calves perished in the flames. The people who gathered there, helped in the saving of the other out buildings, and also from the sparks causing a prairie fire.

I would gauge the wind blowing at the time to be between 30 and 40 mile an hour wind, and as this kept up all night, I returned to the school at 6 p.m. and waited until 11 pm. for the fire to get down to a reasonable size, it taking quite a period for the hay to burn down. When I left the embers were still burning, but with very little flame, and the principal had men on guard duty all night. We have one thing to be thankful for and that is that the wind was in the west, with no chance of sparks falling on the school.

I discussed the question of the Milk herd with the Principal, this can be temporary placed in the long Implement shed, until it is possible to replace the barn; In this connection if it is the dept's wish to rebuild lumber for completion will be hard to get, however a barn could be put up as a shell to be completed when finished lumber is available. This however can be taken up after the debris has been cleared up and the state of the Foundation is inspected.

I also discussed the question of Feed with Mr. Cole they having lost their whole winters feed, and I offered him a small stack of 1942 old hay at the C.Y. Ranch, which we do not intend to use, I can also if it is the wish of the Branch spare him some from my surplus from last year. I also gathered the Indians together and suggested to them that they put on a bee and put up as much possible before the weather breaks.

The children were allowed to go home for twenty four hours in case of a change of wind causing the sparks to travel over the direction of the school.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6370, file 763-5, part 6)
The older boys were kept so that help would be available if needed.

After looking over the situation and discussing it with the Principal Mr. Gold, and Mr. Irwin it would look apparent that the fire was caused by combustion in the loft; I checked with Mr. Irwin re the lighting of the barn, but found that during the day the main switch had been pulled, and he was satisfied that there was no possible chance of a short circuit. The children were all in their class rooms, except for a few small boys and girls playing in the grounds close to the school.

I would be glad to have the Branch's instructions as to whether immediate action will be taken to replace this building, or whether a temporary structure will be built to house the Milk cows. If such action is thought off, nails are practically not purchaseable, and it would be necessary if the Branch can locate any to have them shipped out from the East. At present building in this District is completely stopped through lack of nails.

This completes my report on the fire which I am very sorry to have to report.

(Sgd) Anthony McMillan,
Indian Agent.
