Your letter of November 6th at hand and we wish to thank you for authorizing us to go ahead with the two schools.

Am enclosing tender as you suggest but have made two changes from the original.

1st: Have changed rib top and bottom to pressure type bronze. It is not practical to use rib material with AA parting stop as the parting stop allows for expansion and contraction of sash due to weather conditions. Rib material can only be used where all members are rigidly held together, bronze is the more flexible and is ideal and advocated by the manufacturers of AA strip.

2nd: Have made any extra work on an hourly rate of $1.25 which is fair.

If these changes are acceptable we shall commence work immediately upon arrival of the necessary materials.

As there are only two sizes of windows, we would appreciate it if the widths and heights of openings were taken by someone at the school and forwarded immediately. The measurement to be taken between jambs and from head jamb to sill. Measurement of one window of each size is sufficient.

It would be advisable if the pulley ropes were examined for breakage and frayed ropes and that replacement rope of the correct diameter be available. Also, any broken lights that require replacement should be counted and the sizes required should also be made available along with putty.

As soon as these sizes reach me will order the necessary materials.

There is no possibility of commencing work before January. This we trust is satisfactory, as materials are very slow in delivery.

Yours very truly,

Memorandum:

SURVEYS AND ENGINEERING

Care and Maintenance of Electrical Plants in Indian Residential Schools.

Our Branch is now publishing a magazine called "The Indian School Bulletin" for all our branch officials, principals and teachers.

It has long been felt that more care should be taken with the electrical and mechanical equipment placed in our residential schools. We have recently received a typical report from the Southern Alberta Electric Limited concerning conditions at two Indian residential schools in Pelican Agency. The principal reported to the Agent that twice recently there had been instances of bulbs blowing out and sockets and electric wiring burning. Fortunately, in both instances there happened to be a member of the staff in the room when this had happened. Therefore, Mr. Indian Agent McMillan, in view of the evident fire hazard, called in the above company for an emergency inspection. I attach a copy of the above company's reports on both these schools.

Would it be possible to have an article prepared for a future issue of our magazine entitled "The Care and Maintenance of the Electrical Plants in Residential Schools" so that we may draw to the attention of all concerned the absolute necessity of careful maintenance and common sense in the use of the electrical plants provided.
Memorandum to Surveys & Engineering. Feb. 3, 1947.

In the instance of these two schools we have requested Mr. Indian Agent McMillan to obtain estimates immediately upon the emergency repairs that will have to be carried out. It is felt that one of your engineers from Banff might visit these two schools in the near future to further report upon this situation.

Director.
c/c to Inspector Gooderham

G H Gooderham Esqr Inspector of Indian Agencies Calgary.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 26th ult File 116-4B-2 regarding the St Cyprian School barn, also the Building at Macleod Airport under the heading of building No 41.

I have noted the remarks, and concur, the Building not being suitable without a large expenditure being made on it; I have also noted the point of the necessity of the School having a Barn, and have made a sketch of the Floor plan approximately to the same size and space, as the old one.

In doing this I have made no effort to show a Front or side view of the barn, as the old one was built on the Hip roof type, which gave accommodation for 50 Tons of hay, I would more favor just a small loft, which could be filled weekly, and therefore at no time have the possibility of instantaneous combustion. The barn is badly needed, and if it can be built this year it should be done, as the temporary accommodation will not suffice the next winter.

The question of the state of the cement floor if Iron cow stalls are going to be put in, would have to checked by a man qualified to do so, as this cement took an awful licking from the heat, when the fire was at its worst.

Re: Barn, St. Cyprian's Residential School, Keigan Reserve
referring to your letter of May 22nd,

was made in the current year's appropriation to erect a
barn for this school. A barn is needed, and attached
hereto is copy of a letter and sketch prepared by the
Indian agent. The sketch merely indicates the space
that would be required; it does not indicate the type
of barn that might be constructed.

It is our considered opinion that the
barn should not have a loft, but that hay and roughage
might be stored in stacks, or in a shed adjoining the
barn. The construction would be simple and not so
costly.

As you will, no doubt, have many plans
of barns, no attempt will be made to submit an idea of
what the construction would be.

As for cost, it would be a wild guess
to say that it should not cost over $5,000.00 fully
equipped.

At your convenience, please advise what
may be expected.

Alberta Inspectorate.

Sir,

I beg to advise that this week I visited the St Cyprians Residential School with a view to checking over with Principal the necessary repairs to the above School.

As this will incur a very large expenditure I will be glad to receive your advice as to what can be done under the Estimates, and also if any further sum will be spent on the larger requests.

Some of the items are what would be classed Emergency repairs, while others come under the Estimates asked for every year.

The following are the items quoted by the Principal:

1. Chimney
   The large chimney arising about 40 feet above the annex, was examined and it was found that numerous bricks are loosening up around the base, with some of them right out. Inspection of this chimney, especially the base should be made by someone who knows, and the necessary repairs made.

2. Painting
   I have been advised by the Principal that during last year he used with labor from the staff approximately 25 gallons of paint for inside decoration, this pain being the property of the School, the Principal would like the value of the paint placed to the outside painting of the School Building. As quoted under the letter of the Sacred Heart School which is the same size, it would mean the purchase of at least 50 Gallons Linseed Oil and 250 Cans White Lead 25 Lbs. There is no question that the schools should be repainted with window trim on the windows.

3. Dormitory
   The laying of the floor in the boys dormitory is badly needed and the cost will approximate $400.00. This floor is badly rutted with the cuts made by the castors on the beds, and in some places the floor is worn right through. This is the boys dormitory the boys dormitory having been done.

4. Linoleum
   Battle ship linoleum is asked for the floors of the following room with the yardage shown alongside of the room, Boys Play Room 55 Yards, Girls Playroom 50 Yds Hall 25 Yards, Hall No 2, 40 yards, Dining Room 50 Yds a total of 260 sq yards.

5. Lockers
   The lockers in the boys dormitory are completely gone and will have to be replaced, this would mean two sides of the room with boot lockers, with cover for the seats.

Items in last years Estimates according to available funds.

The Crash Panels in the Above school is now being done by the Principals Father in Law at an very small cost, and will be vouchered for when completed this School both the school and outbuildings are badly in need of a coat of paint.
coat of paint, and I would like to have your opinion as to whether sufficient funds will be available to do work of this kind as it will be necessary in next year's estimates to include all the items brought forward in this letter.

I might state that today I have been advised of a change of Principals at this school, but I do not think that this will change the programme.

I will be glad to receive your authority of the amount allowed, and also whether other items will be taken care of, when I will get all the necessary figures prepared.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: St. Cyprian's Indian Residential School,
Brocket, Alberta.

The above mentioned school is located in the Leigam Indian Agency and is operated under the auspices of the Church of England.

On October 23rd, 1946, the barn at this school was destroyed by fire. For the past few months we have been endeavouring to obtain a building from one of the airports or army camps in the vicinity but our efforts in this regard have been unsuccessful.

Reverend Canon Alderwood, Secretary of the M.S.C.C., interviewed Departmental officials recently and urged that the new barn be built immediately. Canon Alderwood states that he could arrange to erect a suitable barn at a cost not exceeding $5,000.

Owing to conditions over which we have no control, our proposed building plans for the current year are proceeding very slowly and as a result there will be a considerable amount of money unexpended in the sub-allotment "Construction of Buildings and Works".
In view of the necessity of providing a barn at the St. Cyprian's School before the winter, I would appreciate it if the Minister would approve the use of $5,000, for the purpose from the sub-allotment in the appropriation mentioned above.

Director.

Dear Sir:

Re: Peigan Reserve - Brocket, Alberta.

On Tuesday July 15 I visited Brocket and examined the Protestant/School Building and have now to report as follows:

(1) Regarding the boiler chimney, this chimney is in no danger of toppling because of high winds and does not present any hazard to the life of the occupants of the building. However, at the point where the chimney emerges from the roof the boiler house attention should be given to the brickwork. First of all proper flashing and counter flashing should be installed, as shown on the accompanying drawing, marked detail "A". When the flashing and counter flashing has been installed the brickwork should be pointed out with cement, mortar or asphalt gum. This is properly a tinsmith and roofer's job and I would strongly urge that you have a qualified man do the work.

(2) Regarding the kitchen chimney I would recommend that the loose bricks at the top be removed and that it be recapped with a concrete cap, in the manner shown in detail "B" attached.

(3) Regarding the roof the main building I would suggest that

(a) New down pipe be installed from the three hoppers to the main waste, i.e., the horizontal pipes be renewed complete with roof receivers of an approved type, the minimum construction being as shown on detail "C" attached. In order to install these receivers it will be necessary to remove the roofing for a distance of about 4 feet all round each receive and to replace it at the time the receiver is being installed. This work should also be done by an approved roofer.

(b) Around the flashings and parapets the roof has perished and the following treatment is necessary.

Scrape off the gravel back from the flashings for a distance of about 15 inches. Install two ply of 15
pound roofing felt, carried up underneath the galvanized iron flashing and out onto the roof, the felt to be solidly mopped to the existing roofing and solidly mopped between the piles. After the felt is in place regravel up to the flashing. This work should be done by an approved roofer.

(4) I would recommend that the various actions mentioned above be carried out at the earliest possible date, and certainly during this summer. I feel that these are emergency repairs and that the public interest will suffer if the work is not put in hand.

I trust that this report will be of value to you. If there is anything else that I can do, do not hesitate to call on me.

(sgd.) D. A Freeze,
District Resident Architect.

Dear Colonel Neary:

I have your letter of 25th September on the above subject and would advise that during the past week action has been taken to procure prices on materials for construction of this building.

When the matter was considered early in 1945, it was proposed to erect a 1½ storey building 75' x 45' with full-sized basement partly above grade - the allocation of space to be

(a) Basement Kitchen, Dining Room, Staff Dining Room, Play Room, Furnace Room, Stores and Fuel.

(b) Main Floor Boys Dormitory, Girls Dormitory, Staff Living Room, Infirmary, Offices, Lavatories, etc.

(c) Attic or Upper Half Storey General Storage

The type of construction contemplated was solid masonry walls of local field stone for the basement, which would have a concrete floor. The walls of the main portion of the building were to be of logs obtained in the vicinity. The balance of the material required was to be finished lumber, doors, windows, cement gyproc, roofing, etc., shipped in from Edmonton.

Early in 1945, a bill of materials for a building as described above and an estimate of cost of the items not available locally at Wabasca were prepared for us by the W. H. Clark Lumber Co. Ltd. of Edmonton. However, in view of the general increase in prices since that time, we wrote them on 25th Sept. asking them to favour us with a revised estimate and
also with an estimate of freight charges on this material from Edmonton to Slave Lake.

Also on 25th September we wrote (via air mail) the Principal at Wabasca asking if he could get a price locally for the supply of the necessary logs and their delivery to the site by the middle of March next. At the same time we asked him to report the approximate cost of procuring locally next spring the estimated 20 cords of field stone, 60 cubic yards of gravel and 30 cubic yards of sand required for the basement floor and walls.

As soon as replies are received to the inquiries indicated above, we should like to discuss the project with you in detail. We appreciate fully the need for early action in order to take advantage of the appropriation in your Departmental Estimates for the current fiscal year.

Yours sincerely,

Indian Affairs Branch

Re Repairs to Night Watchman's Clock.

Yesterday the Principal of St Cyprians School came to the Office re the Night Watchmans clock, which is out of order and re which he had been in correspondence with the Chicago Watch Clock Division, re having a replacement while getting their clock repaired.

I find that the Customs at Lethbridge will not release the replacement until Duty of $11.80 is paid, and as this clock to my belief is the Property of the Indian Affairs Branch I feel before I take this clock out I should get your advice as to whether we are dutiable, or whether the Branch knos of a place in Canada where this clock can be repaired, before I accept the customs notice.

May I have a reply by return.

According to the information on the clock this should have been sent away for cleaning in 1947.

Mr. A. McMillan,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Brocket, Alberta.

Re: St. Cyprian's Indian Residential School. Your File 116-13-1

With reference to the repairs to the night watchman's clock at the above school, it is regretted that your letter is not clear to us.

It might be inferred from the first part of the second paragraph of your letter that the clock had already been sent to the United States for repairs, and on its return the clock was being held at the Customs Office at Lethbridge for payment of duty in the amount of $11.80.

Further to your letter of the 8th inst regarding my letter re the repairs of the Night Watchmans clock.

What did happen the Principal wrote to Chicago Watchmans Clock Co., asking for a clock to replace the one they had in use at the School, which they intended to send there as soon as the replacement arrived. When the replacement arrived he was advised by Customs at Lethbridge that the duty on the clock being sent for replacement was $11.80.

He then came to me, and brought the clock for repair with him and that is when I wrote you, regarding the Duty on the clock for temporary replacement, which will be returned to Chicago when the original clock has been repaired and returned.

The remark in the latter portion of the second paragraph re whether the clock could be repaired in Canada was so if that was possible the replacement would be sent back.

The ownership of this clock is Department, and Vouchers 86 and 87 for $38.59, and $15.20 respectively sent forward on September 25th 1946 were paid by the Department. There has been three changes of Principals since then, and they would not know at present where the clock came from.

May I have authority to pay the Duty, and also have the clock repaired, so that we will have the clock in shape to have the Night Watchman punch it according to the rules governing the Night Watchman's duties.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Re: Snow Clearance, Brocket

In reference to the account for $50 submitted by Superintendent A. McMillan on January 24th, 1950.

When we received the account the following questions were asked of the Principal and the following answers received.

Question (a) When you "inquired in mid December about having your road opened and the snow blade was sent" was it attached to an Indian Affairs Tractor or Sacred Heart Tractor or a hired tractor?

Answer (a) The snow blade was attached to the Sacred Heart Tractor.

Question (b) About what date was the bull-dozer used for which the account of $50.00 has been submitted?

Answer (b) Date of Thursday January 19th, 1950 (Evening).

Question (c) Have you ever asked McMillan to let you have the snow plow blade for use with your own tractor and, if so, what was his reply?

Answer (c) No. Soon after the middle of December the snow was too deep to clear with a light tractor.

The following information is also pertinent.

When Principal Woods enquired about use of the snow blade (mid-December) it was sent to a point ½ mile from the school and has never been used by St. Cyprian's.

The Principal did not ask that the road be opened at the time for which the bill of $50 is submitted. He claimed that there was no thaw forecast and that the road was completely blocked again within three days of its being cleared.

(P.T.O.)

Re: Telephone Lines - Sacred Heart & St. Cyprian's Residential School, Pelican Agency.

This office received a copy of Superintendent McKillan's letter to you of February 14th dealing with a telephone line that connects the system at Brocket with the two residential schools on the Pelican Reserve. Although we have no further correspondence on file, I took the matter up with Superintendent McKillan on my recent visit to his Agency and he showed me your wire of April 19th in which you stated that you were submitting his letter to the Minister, as no funds had been specifically provided in the 1950/51 appropriation to rebuild the telephone lines.

We have just concluded a search of Commissioner Graham's file and we have found that these two lines were erected in 1927 and 1928. Correspondence indicates that the Department's share in the cost at that time was $300.00 per school. This apparently provided all the materials needed to complete the installation and approximately $185.00 left over from the Department's contribution was used to pay at least part of the cost of labour required to install the service. It is assumed that the schools themselves took care of any additional costs involved, if there were any. Our files make no mention of this except that the total of $600.00 was to have been the only contribution made by the Department towards the cost of installation.

Mr. McKillan informed me that if the Alberta Government Telephones reconstruct these lines for us, the cost would exceed $4,000.00. I considered this excessive, therefore, I interviewed Mr. J. Boorman, the local manager of the Alberta Government Telephones at Macleod in which I found that at the outset the poles would have to be replaced over a distance of 8 miles, requiring from 30 to 32 poles per mile with minimum height each of 20 feet. Not only would these poles be expensive but they are a type which only the Alberta Government Telephones can supply. In addition to this the wire would have to be checked and if not replaced, certainly splices would have to be made in many places. Also involved is the installation of insulation and side blocks requiring expensive materials and the services of qualified servicemen. I conclude that even if we could obtain all necessary materials, it would be doubtful if we could effect any appreciable saving over the price quoted by Alberta Government Telephones.
I do not think there is any point in endeavouring to establish whether or not telephone service to these schools is required. The service was considered necessary in 1927 and can be considered just as much a necessity today. Since the poor condition of these telephone lines is causing a serious disruption of service in the whole system in the Brocket area, Alberta Government Telephones want an early reply. If we decide to not place the lines in good condition, they will disconnect this portion of the system.

This letter is written for information only.

G. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Re: St. Cyprian's Residential School, Peigan Indian Reserve

During an inspection of this school on the 20th, the Principal stated that it was nearly impossible to keep the west end of the building warm during the winter months. Considerable has been done during the past three years to make this building more weather-proof; all windows were reather-stripped in 1948, and in 1949 it was covered with insul-brick. There is some additional work to be done on the insul-brick as the contractor had not fully finished this job when the weather became very cold.

The winds from the west and south-west are terrible in this District, and the day I visited, it could be felt on the inside of the west wall at many points. The Reverend Mr. Woods stated that during the winter it was actually freezing inside the west wall when the east wall of the building was too hot. Would it not be good business to have an engineer inspect the heating plant and make the necessary corrections? There are no Indian Affairs field officials capable of making this inspection, and there certainly is no one on the school staff.

The girls' basement washroom is at the west end of this building and I marvel that all the pipes had not burst for the plaster walls are broken and there is nothing to prevent the wind and cold getting in. Much the same condition is evident in the pupils' dining-room. These walls must be repaired, and I don't recommend that they be plastered again. Some good hard composition board, with insulation behind it, should replace this plaster. If money is available, kindly advise and Superintendent MacMillan will obtain tenders.

This institution needs an electric ironer (mangle). The laundry is small and the pupils who should be in class spend hours with the flat irons.

There are 57 children on the roll, and I was satisfied that Mr. Woods and his staff are trying to run a reasonably good school. This cannot be expected unless the building is properly equipped and in good physical condition. It was noted that some pupils were working in the kitchen and the laundry, when they should be in school, and no doubt they could be in class if there was more modern equipment.

This residential school, like many others, must carry on for years, unless the Day school programme is speeded up. I, therefore hope that serious consideration can be given to the requests.

G.H. Gooderham,

In company with Mr. Cameron, Mr. McMillan saw the manager at Macleod, who in turn directed him to his superior at Lethbridge, who also refused to make a decision and referred him to Mr. Thos. Spalding, General Commercial Superintendent at Edmonton. Mr. McMillan wrote to Mr. Spalding and his reply has not yet been received.

I considered this procedure necessary so that there will be no avenue left open for the telephone company to refuse service at some future date. I don't know what the reply will be from Mr. Spalding but by using the old poles a saving of $1,150.00 is effected and should be considered.

In the final analysis, will not the decision rest with our Branch, if we are assured that the poles are sound and then properly creosoted and set, would we not be justified in accepting Mr. Cameron's lower tender?

You should receive this letter as early as a wire can reach you after hearing from Mr. Spalding and then be in a position to make a decision and wire instructions.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Re: Anglican Indian Residential School
Brocket, Alberta.

In a letter written July first Principal Woods reports that after a hailstorm on that date the melting hailstones on the roof of the school created quite a flood in the building. This flooding after snow or rain is no new experience at St. Cyprian's and has been reported to the Agency Superintendent a number of times. Requisitions for roofing and pipes have been placed also but apparently they get no farther than the superintendent's office desk.

Dr. Stone was on visit to the school at the time of the hailstorm and I understand from the Principal that he (Dr. Stone) is submitting a report on his observations to the Regional Supervisor of Agencies, Calgary. What Mr. Gooderham's action will be I know not but the situation is a critical one; to the building itself and to the health of children and staff. Sewer gas repeatedly backs up and permeates the building with an unsavory odour which is proof that something is wrong with the septic tank.

A few extracts from Principal Woods letter will give you an idea of what conditions are like:

"DRAIN Pipes: when the hail was thawing on the roof the water gushed out of the split and corroded pipes, again (for the second time) flooded the boys dormitory - a stream, like a creek came down the stair way to the basement. That is nothing unusual, it occurs every time there is a heavy shower. The dormitory floor does not hold water consequently it poured through into the Senior Class room and into the Staff rooms, running down the electric light equipment. Inspite of catching as much as possible with wash tubs, boilers and pails and scooping it up with dustpans, etc., still it came through in the staff sitting room. Our Chapel was spared and consequently our appartment was protected. This was because we had detected the sewer gases coming through the roof..."
drain pipes in the girls dormitory and Irwin and I had found these pipes to be corroded - through and then packed the split with putty and wrapped flannelet sheeting around the split pipes, this checked the force of water coming into that dormitory; fortunately the girls supervisor was on the job and worked desperately to prevent the bed being soaked and water going through the floor. Apparently we must get more putty and sheeting and wrap more pipes. For years the pipe over the Boys Supervisor's room has been split and wrapped. Today the chief offending pipe was over the entrance to the boys dormitory. I am pleased to report that I had invited Dr. Stone -- Regional Supervisor of Health Services -- to come for consultations, I brought him out from Brocket and the hall commenced as he entered the School. I called him up stairs to see for himself how the roof water gushes out of the pipes. After helping the few staff members to scoop-up and mop floors I returned to the apartment, there I found Dr. Stone writing a report on the infernal deluge; upon finding that he was reporting it to the local Agent I commented that that would lay on his desk with my requisitions and sundry estimates for roofing and pipe estimates, he then wrote another report to the Regional Supervisor of Agencies, Calgary. I trust you will convey the urgency of this matter to the Indian Affairs Branch. It is not reasonable to expect the staff to remain here another week, and be flooded out, and with the sewer gases backing up into the children's dormatory, and the rain water coming onto their beds. Neither is it reasonable to have them back while the Principal is responsible for their health. I understand, for ten years the roof has leaked and estimates have been going into the Indian Affairs Branch. For four or five years these pipes have been spilling water in the dormitories. Although I have made requisition regarding the sceptic tank and these pipes and urged contractors and the Agent to get things moving, I find that to yesterdays date nothing was further than the estimate stage in the local office."

I look upon this situation as an emergency and trust that Indian Affairs Branch will take immediate action.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

HGC/PAL

Superintendent.

Mr. Osterberg erected the Day school and appears to be a conscientious, capable workman and I believe Mr. McMillan will have difficulty in getting a competitive offer.

The replacement or repair to the roof and down pipes which are leaking badly and allowing sewer gas to escape throughout the building is Number One. The replacement or repair of the roof Number Two and the wall repairs in the basement third.

To carry out the entire program would cost over $6000.00, based on the present offers. The physical condition of this school is not good and sooner or later this expenditure must be made. If money is available now, it is recommended that a competent engineer inspect it and call for definite type of work to be done. If this cannot be done right away, the down pipes in the school should be replaced immediately and other replacements follow in due course of time. However, all of it should be done during the summer holidays.

AIR MAIL

February 11, 1943.

Mr. G.H. Gooderham, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Public Building, Calgary, Alberta.

We forwarded you a copy of our letter to the late
Canon Alderwood dated July 15th, 1947 in connection with
the erection of a new barn at the St. Cyprian's Indian
Residential School. The Indian Agent was also advised
about the matter and he subsequently advised us that he
was assisting the principal in arranging for the new barn.

On October 4th we forwarded Mr. McMillan a telegram,
a copy of which I enclose and following a telegram received
from him we sent the Indian Agent an accountable advance of
$2,000.00 for labour. We heard nothing further from him
regarding the barn until December when he forwarded a voucher
requesting an additional $500.00 over and above the $2,000.
advance. From the information on the voucher it appeared
that either the principal or the Agent had made a contract
with Mr. O. Playford for the labour. We requested and re-
ceived a copy of this contract and I enclose copy of same
for your information.

It was a very irregular procedure for the Agent to
award a contract amounting to $2,500. No official at head
office can do this without the Deputy Minister's approval.

We are having some difficulty in having the account
passed for payment by the Treasury Branch and we would ap-
preciate it if you would let us have an early report on
the barn, stating if you consider that we received full
value for the money paid to Playford.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

It was well equipped, and in my opinion the best value for the amount of money spent that I had seen in recent years. I complimented both the Agent and Mr. Cole on the very fine job they had done.

As for payment to Mr. Playford, it is hardly necessary to say that his contract was well within the amount that would be normally charged to a building costing $5,000.00. As you know, labor costs on such invariably run to 60% of the total cost and in this instance, it is only 50%. I have no hesitation in recommending payment.

Attention B F NEary Esqr.

In reply to your letter of the 26th June 1948 File 116-1-5 re the Pressure tank at the St Cyrians Residential School.

A short time ago one of the tanks started a leak and I had the plumber disconnect the tank and place the fittings directly to the other, and asked the plumber to get a price on another Tank, which he is now doing; the tank now in use has been repaired at times, the tank is shown on my letter on what has been allowed for this year, and with the wall having to be cut to get a new tank in will run high.

In regard to the school as a whole I am rather in a quandry, as practically all the time I am dealing with the Farm Instructor, or a junior member of the staff; as with Rev Cole being appointed to Gleichen, and only coming on short visits about two weeks a year, I have not much chance in an emergency, would it not be possible for the Macc to decide on a new Principal, or place authority in someone at the school.

Anthony M Miller
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch Dept of Mines & Resources Ottawa.

I have been in touch with the Principal of St Cyprians Indian Residential School regarding the Estimates for this year, and was advised during Mr Turner's visit here that $3000.00 had been allowed for each school. On this basis I discussed with the Farm Instructor, who is the only responsible man there re what they wished to have done and the following is their request.

| Item          | Cost   |
|---------------|--------|
| Root House    | $450.00|
| Overhaul      | $300.00|
| Painting Barn | $1000.00|
| Pressure Tank | $600.00 |
| Emergency     | $450.00 |

The prices shown are just Estimates, and may be more or less, but have taken no bids till I receive instructions that the above sum is allowed.

May I have your instructions regarding the amount allowed, and also which manner you wish me to have the estimates done, such as by Requisition or local purchase, and accountable cheques.

Attention B F Neary Esqr.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Early in April, 1948, you advised me that the following funds are provided in your estimates, 1948-49, for the above-named school:

"New roothouse and painting and repairs to staff rooms and residence $3,000.00

Refrigeration equipment 850.00"

I have just received word from this school that they are worried about the roothouse as your local Agent informs them that he has not yet received any authority for this work. I can assure you, from personal inspection, that the present structure is not only useless but is unsafe for anyone to enter. As the school has 1/2 acres of potatoes planted, in addition to other vegetables, it is of great importance that the roothouse be rebuilt before the crops are harvested and it is requested, therefore, that your Agent be given authority to proceed with the work of rebuilding as early as possible.

The report from the school also contains the following:

"There are several small repair jobs around the school which really should be attended to while the children are away; for example, some tables in the children's dining room need bracing and a few extra tacks and a coat of paint. Some places in the lower part of the dining room walls need patching with plaster and the whole lower half painting. The wash rooms need cement repairing, the kitchen also should have a coat of paint on the lower part and the floors of the halls and stairs around the battleship linoleum need stain varnishing, etc."

p.t.o.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6370, file 763-5, part 8)
It is requested that your Agent be authorized to have these minor repairs and painting carried out during the holiday period this summer. It is not very desirable to have wet paint around while small children are in residence if this can be avoided by carrying out the work when they are away.

May I be advised as early as convenient as to what you can do in regard to the above services.

Yours truly,
